judges: C. Lycourgos;L.S. Rossi;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: GDPR consent is required for including subscriber personal data in telephone directories published by third-party providers, and such consent may be given to the operator or any directory provider.
provisions_cited: Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58;Article 2(f) Directive 2002/58;Article 95 GDPR;Article 4(11) GDPR;Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
semantic_quote: Article 4(11) of the GDPR, which constitutes the provision applicable to the facts at issue in the main proceedings, defines the 'consent of the data subject' as requiring a 'freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous' indication of the data subject's wishes in the form of a statement or of 'a clear affirmative action' signifying agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her.
systematic_quote: It follows from a contextual and systematic interpretation of Article 12 of Directive 2002/58 that the consent under Article 12(2) relates to the purpose of the publication of personal data in a public directory and not to the identity of any particular directory provider.
teleological_quote: Article 1(1) of Directive 2002/58 provides, inter alia, for the harmonisation of the national provisions required to ensure an equivalent level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms, and in particular the right to privacy and confidentiality, with regard to the processing of personal data in the electronic communications sector.
direction_justification: Confirms that GDPR-standard consent is required for directory inclusion, strengthening subscriber control over personal data publication.

judges: C. Lycourgos;L.S. Rossi;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: A subscriber's request to withdraw personal data from telephone directories constitutes exercise of the right to erasure under Article 17 GDPR.
provisions_cited: Article 17 GDPR;Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58;Article 6(1)(a) GDPR;Article 7(3) GDPR;Article 16 GDPR;Article 95 GDPR
semantic_quote: Under the second sentence of Article 12(2) of Directive 2002/58, subscribers must have, inter alia, the opportunity to have the personal data relating to them withdrawn from public directories.
systematic_quote: However, the grant of such an opportunity to subscribers does not constitute, as regards the providers of directories, a specific obligation, within the meaning of Article 95 of the GDPR, which would make it possible to exclude the application of the relevant provisions of that regulation.
teleological_quote: Directive 2002/58 does not contain any indications as to the modalities, implementation and consequences of requests to obtain the withdrawal of personal data.
direction_justification: Classifies withdrawal requests as erasure rights under Article 17 GDPR, giving subscribers stronger legal protection than mere rectification.

judges: C. Lycourgos;L.S. Rossi;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: A DPA may require directory providers to take measures to inform third-party controllers (operators and other directory providers) of a subscriber's consent withdrawal.
provisions_cited: Article 5(2) GDPR;Article 24 GDPR;Article 19 GDPR;Article 7(3) GDPR;Article 12(2) GDPR;Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
semantic_quote: Article 24 of the GDPR, that provision requires that, taking into account the nature, scope, context and purposes of processing, the controller implement appropriate technical and organisational measures to ensure and to be able to demonstrate that processing is performed in accordance with that regulation.
systematic_quote: It follows from the general obligations laid down in Article 5(2) and Article 24 of the GDPR, read in conjunction with Article 19 thereof, that a controller of personal data, such as Proximus, must, by means of appropriate technical and organisational measures, inform the other providers of directories that have received such data from it of the withdrawal of the data subject's consent addressed to it.
teleological_quote: In order to ensure the effectiveness of the right of the data subject to withdraw his or her consent provided for in Article 7(3) of the GDPR and to ensure that the data subject's consent is strictly linked to the purpose for which it was given, the controller to which the data subject has notified the withdrawal of his or her consent to the processing of his or her personal data is in fact required to communicate that withdrawal to any person who has forwarded those data to it and to the person to whom it has, in turn, forwarded those data.
direction_justification: Imposes chain notification obligations on controllers to facilitate consent withdrawal, making it easier for subscribers to exercise their rights.

judges: C. Lycourgos;L.S. Rossi;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: A DPA may order directory providers to take reasonable steps to inform search engines of erasure requests from subscribers.
semantic_quote: Article 17(2) of the GDPR imposes the obligation on the controller which has made the personal data public, taking account of available technology and the cost of implementation, to take reasonable steps, including technical measures, to inform controllers which are processing the personal data that the data subject has requested the erasure by such controllers of any links to, or copy or replication of, those personal data.
teleological_quote: As is apparent from recital 66 of the GDPR, the objective of that obligation is to strengthen the right to be forgotten in the online environment, and therefore specifically applies to information made available on the internet by search engine providers that process data published online.
direction_justification: Extends directory providers' obligations to include notifying search engines, strengthening the right to be forgotten in the online environment.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;L. Bay Larsen;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: The remedies under Articles 77-79 GDPR may be exercised concurrently and independently, with Member States setting procedural rules ensuring effective protection and consistent application.
semantic_quote: Thus, those provisions of Regulation 2016/679 offer different remedies to persons claiming that that regulation has been infringed, it being understood that each of those remedies must be capable of being exercised 'without prejudice' to the others.
systematic_quote: Although the EU legislature has expressly regulated the relationship between the remedies provided for by Regulation 2016/679 in the event of the supervisory authorities or courts of several Member States being seised simultaneously in respect of an instance of processing of personal data carried out by the same controller, it must be observed that this is not the case as regards the remedies provided for in Articles 77 to 79 of that regulation.
teleological_quote: Lastly, regarding the objectives pursued by that regulation, it is apparent, in particular, from recital 10 thereof that the aim of that regulation is to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data within the European Union.
direction_justification: Permits data subjects to pursue multiple remedies concurrently, maximizing avenues for enforcement of their rights.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;L. Bay Larsen;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: The right of access under Article 15(1)(c) GDPR entails an obligation to provide data subjects with the actual identity of recipients to whom their data have been disclosed, unless identification is impossible or the request is manifestly unfounded or excessive.
semantic_quote: It should be noted that the terms 'recipients' and 'categories of recipient' in that provision are used in succession, without it being possible to infer an order of priority between them.
systematic_quote: In the fourth place, the Court has previously held that the exercise of that right of access must enable the data subject to verify not only that the data concerning him or her are correct, but also that they are processed in a lawful manner, and in particular that they have been disclosed to authorised recipients.
teleological_quote: Lastly, as regards the purpose of the GDPR, it should be pointed out that its purpose is, inter alia, as is apparent from recital 10 of that regulation, to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons within the European Union.
direction_justification: The Court interprets the right of access broadly to require disclosure of specific recipient identities, not just categories, thereby enhancing data subject control over their personal data.
other_rights: rights and freedoms of others

judges: K. Jürimäe;K. Lenaerts;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec;N. Piçarra
core_holding: The exception to the controller's obligation to provide information applies to all personal data not collected directly from the data subject, including data generated by the controller itself.
semantic_quote: It must be noted that the wording of Article 14(5)(c) of the GDPR does not limit the exception which it lays down merely to personal data obtained by the controller from a person other than the data subject, nor does it exclude data generated by the controller itself, in the performance of its tasks, from such data.
systematic_quote: Therefore, it follows from the combined interpretation of Articles 13 and 14 of the GDPR that both personal data obtained by the controller from a person other than the data subject, and data generated by the controller itself – which, on account of their nature, have also not been obtained from the data subject – fall within the scope of Article 14.
teleological_quote: Article 14(5)(c) of the GDPR must be interpreted in a way which is consistent with the objective pursued by that regulation, which consists, inter alia, as is apparent from Article 1 thereof, read in the light of recitals 1 and 10 thereof, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of the exception to information obligations reduces controller burdens by exempting them from providing information for controller-generated data when statutory conditions are met.

judges: K. Jürimäe;K. Lenaerts;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec;N. Piçarra
core_holding: Supervisory authorities are competent to verify whether Member State law provides appropriate protective measures under Article 14(5)(c), but this does not extend to verifying Article 32 security measures.
semantic_quote: The GDPR does not include any provision such as to exclude certain aspects of the application of the exception laid down in Article 14(5)(c) of that regulation from the competence of those supervisory authorities.
systematic_quote: In the light of the respective wording of those two provisions, it should be noted that the obligations enshrined in Article 32 of the GDPR, which must be complied with in all circumstances and irrespective of whether or not there is an obligation to provide information under Article 14 of that regulation, differ in nature and scope from the obligation to provide information laid down in Article 14 of that regulation.
teleological_quote: The provisions of EU or Member State law which provide for such measures and to which the controller is subject must guarantee a level of protection of the data subject with regard to the processing of his or her personal data which is at least equivalent to that provided for in Article 14(1) to (4) of that regulation.
direction_justification: DPA competence is affirmed for verifying protective measures (pro-data subject) but limited by excluding Article 32 security measures from the scope of review (pro-controller).

judges: C. Lycourgos;O. Spineanu-Matei;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: Processing is necessary for contract performance under Article 6(1)(b) only if objectively indispensable for the main contractual purpose, which is not met when the contract expressly prohibits disclosure.
semantic_quote: In order for the processing of personal data to be regarded as necessary for the performance of a contract within the meaning of that provision, it must be objectively indispensable for a purpose that is integral to the contractual obligation intended for the data subject.
systematic_quote: The essential feature of acquiring an indirect shareholding, through a trust company, in an investment fund offering shares for public subscription is precisely the anonymity of the partners, including in relations between the partners themselves.
teleological_quote: The objective pursued by the GDPR, as is apparent from Article 1 thereof and recitals 1 and 10 thereof, consists, inter alia, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons.
direction_justification: Sets high threshold for contract necessity requiring objective indispensability, protecting data subjects from disclosure contrary to contractual expectations.

judges: C. Lycourgos;O. Spineanu-Matei;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: Legitimate interests processing under Article 6(1)(f) requires strict necessity and a balancing test where data subject interests may override, particularly when disclosure was not reasonably expected.
semantic_quote: That provision provides that the processing of personal data is lawful if it is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject.
systematic_quote: The condition relating to the need for processing must be examined in conjunction with the 'data minimisation' principle enshrined in Article 5(1)(c) of the GDPR.
teleological_quote: Recital 47 of the GDPR states that the interests and fundamental rights of the data subject may in particular override the interest of the data controller where personal data are processed in circumstances where data subjects do not reasonably expect such processing.
direction_justification: Court emphasizes strict necessity, less intrusive alternatives, data minimisation, and reasonable expectations favoring data subject protection over third party interests.

judges: C. Lycourgos;O. Spineanu-Matei;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: Legal obligation under Article 6(1)(c) can derive from Member State case-law provided it is clear, precise, foreseeable, meets a public interest objective, and is proportionate.
semantic_quote: That provision provides that the processing of personal data is lawful if processing is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject.
systematic_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR specifies, inter alia, in that respect, that the processing must be based on EU law or on Member State law to which the controller is subject.
teleological_quote: That legal basis must meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.
direction_justification: Court sets out conditions for legal obligation basis without definitively ruling whether German case-law meets them, leaving determination to national court.

judges: E. Regan;K. Lenaerts;C. Lycourgos;I. Jarukaitis;M. Ilešič
core_holding: The collection by tax authorities of a Member State from an economic operator of personal data is subject to GDPR requirements, including Article 5(1) principles.
semantic_quote: Under Article 4(2) of that regulation, the collection, consultation, disclosure by transmission and making available in any way of personal data constitute 'processing' within the meaning of that regulation.
systematic_quote: It is apparent from recital 19 of Regulation 2016/679, the reason for that exception is that the processing of personal data for such purposes by the competent authorities is governed by a specific EU legal act, namely Directive 2016/680, which was adopted on the same day as Regulation 2016/679.
teleological_quote: As is apparent from recital 10 thereof, Regulation 2016/679 aims, inter alia, to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons within the European Union.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of GDPR scope confirms tax authorities are subject to data protection requirements when collecting personal data.

judges: E. Regan;K. Lenaerts;C. Lycourgos;I. Jarukaitis;M. Ilešič
core_holding: Tax authorities cannot derogate from Article 5(1) GDPR unless granted that right by a legislative measure meeting Article 23(1) requirements.
semantic_quote: However, Article 23 of Regulation 2016/679 authorises the European Union and Member States to adopt a 'legislative measure' restricting the scope of the obligations and rights provided for, inter alia, in Article 5 of that regulation.
systematic_quote: In that regard, it is apparent from recital 41 of Regulation 2016/679 that the reference, in that regulation, to a 'legislative measure' does not necessarily require a legislative act adopted by a parliament.
teleological_quote: As a preliminary point, it should be recalled that, as is apparent from recital 10 thereof, Regulation 2016/679 aims, inter alia, to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons within the European Union.
direction_justification: Requires explicit legislative basis before tax authorities can limit Article 5(1) rights, preventing unilateral derogation by authorities.
other_rights: right to respect for private life;right to protection of personal data

judges: E. Regan;K. Lenaerts;C. Lycourgos;I. Jarukaitis;M. Ilešič
core_holding: Tax authorities may require disclosure of taxpayer data from internet service providers provided the data are necessary for specific purposes and collection period does not exceed strict necessity.
semantic_quote: Article 5(1)(b) of Regulation 2016/679 provides that personal data are to be collected, inter alia, for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes.
systematic_quote: In accordance with Article 5(1)(c) of Regulation 2016/679, personal data are to be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.
teleological_quote: It should be recalled that the collection of tax and combating tax fraud must be regarded as tasks carried out in the public interest within the meaning of point (e) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of Regulation 2016/679.
direction_justification: Permits tax authority data collection but imposes strict necessity and purpose limitation requirements protecting data subjects.

judges: E. Regan;D. Gratsias;M. Ilešič;I. Jarukaitis;Z. Csehi
core_holding: Processing personal data for prosecution serves a different purpose than collection for detection and investigation, but such subsequent processing is permitted under Directive 2016/680 Article 4(2) conditions.
semantic_quote: It is apparent from the various language versions of that provision, in particular those in Bulgarian, Spanish, German, Greek, English and Italian, that the different purposes referred to in Article 1(1) of that directive correspond to the 'prevention', 'detection', 'investigation' and 'prosecution' of criminal offences and 'the execution of criminal penalties', including the 'safeguarding' against 'threats to public security' and the 'prevention' of such threats.
systematic_quote: Article 4(2) of that directive, in the light of recital 29 thereof, authorises subsequent processing of personal data for a purpose other than that for which those data were collected, where that purpose is among those set out in Article 1(1) of that directive and that processing satisfies the two conditions laid down in Article 4(2)(a) and (b).
teleological_quote: It follows from this that the EU legislature sought to adopt rules corresponding to the specific features which characterise the activities carried out by the competent authorities in the field governed by that directive, while taking account of the fact that they constitute distinct activities serving purposes specific to them.
direction_justification: The Court clarifies that different purposes exist but permits subsequent processing under specified conditions, neither expanding nor restricting data subject rights.

judges: E. Regan;D. Gratsias;M. Ilešič;I. Jarukaitis;Z. Csehi
core_holding: The GDPR applies to processing of personal data by a public prosecutor's office when defending the State in civil damages proceedings using data originally collected for criminal purposes.
provisions_cited: Article 3(8) Directive 2016/680;Article 9(1) Directive 2016/680;Article 9(2) Directive 2016/680;Article 2(1) GDPR;Article 2(2) GDPR;Article 4(1) GDPR;Article 4(2) GDPR;Article 4(7) GDPR
semantic_quote: First of all, it must be borne in mind that 'personal data', within the meaning of Article 4(1) of the GDPR, means 'any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person', it being understood that, according to the case-law, that definition is applicable where, by reason of its content, purpose and effect, the information in question is linked to a particular person.
systematic_quote: It is therefore appropriate for those fields to be addressed by a directive that lays down the specific rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties.
teleological_quote: Those definitions reflect the aim of the EU legislature to assign a broad scope to those two concepts.
direction_justification: The Court interprets GDPR scope broadly to include processing by public authorities for civil defense purposes, ensuring data protection applies.

judges: E. Regan;D. Gratsias;M. Ilešič;I. Jarukaitis;Z. Csehi
core_holding: Processing personal data by a public prosecutor's office for State defense in damages proceedings may be lawful under Article 6(1)(e) GDPR as a task carried out in the public interest.
provisions_cited: Article 6(1)(c) GDPR;Article 6(1)(e) GDPR;Article 6(1)(f) GDPR;Article 6(3) GDPR;Article 5(1)(c) GDPR;Article 21(1) GDPR;Article 23(1) GDPR
semantic_quote: It should be noted that, as the Commission correctly stated in its written observations, it is clear from the wording of the second subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR that the processing of personal data by a public authority in the performance of its tasks cannot come within the scope of point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, relating to the processing of personal data that is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller.
systematic_quote: As follows from recital 47 of the GDPR and as the Commission has claimed, that latter provision cannot apply to such data processing, since the legal basis of that processing must be provided for by the legislature.
teleological_quote: First, by exercising the procedural rights that it enjoys as defendant, that public authority preserves the legal certainty of the acts carried out and decisions adopted in the public interest that are being called into question by the applicant.
direction_justification: The Court permits public authorities to process personal data for litigation defense under the public interest basis, facilitating their defensive capabilities.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen
core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82(1) GDPR fulfils an exclusively compensatory function, not a punitive or deterrent one.
semantic_quote: Accordingly, Article 82(1) of the GDPR has been interpreted as meaning that the right to compensation laid down in that provision, in particular in the case of non-material damage, fulfils an exclusively compensatory function, in that financial compensation based on that provision must allow the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in full, and not a deterrent or punitive function.
systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
teleological_quote: The right of any person to seek compensation for damage reinforces the operational nature of the protection rules laid down by that regulation and is likely to discourage the reoccurrence of unlawful conduct.
direction_justification: The holding clarifies the nature of compensation without expanding or restricting rights; it confirms compensation must be full but not punitive.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen
core_holding: The severity and intentional nature of a GDPR infringement need not be taken into account when determining compensation under Article 82(1).
semantic_quote: The exclusively compensatory function of the right to compensation provided for in Article 82(1) of the GDPR precludes taking into account the potentially intentional nature of the infringement of that regulation.
teleological_quote: That amount must, however, be fixed in such a way as to compensate in full for the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation.
direction_justification: The holding benefits controllers by not increasing compensation for intentional violations, but also confirms presumed fault liability.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen
core_holding: Non-material damage from a data breach is not by its nature less significant than physical injury when determining compensation.
semantic_quote: It should also be noted that recitals 75 and 85 of the GDPR set out various circumstances that could be classified as 'physical, material or non-material damage' without establishing a hierarchy between them.
systematic_quote: Recitals 75 and 85 of the GDPR set out various circumstances that could be classified as 'physical, material or non-material damage' without establishing a hierarchy between them nor do they indicate that harm resulting from a data breach is, by its very nature, less significant than physical injury.
teleological_quote: Assuming, as a matter of principle, that physical injury is, by its nature, more serious than non-material damage, would risk calling into question the principle of full and effective compensation for the damage suffered.
direction_justification: Elevating non-material damage to equal status with physical injury strengthens data subject compensation rights.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen
core_holding: Courts may award minimal compensation for non-serious damage provided it fully compensates the damage actually suffered.
semantic_quote: Article 82(1) of the GDPR does not require that, following a proven infringement of provisions of that regulation, the damage alleged by the data subject must reach a 'de minimis threshold' in order to give rise to a right to compensation.
teleological_quote: Such considerations do not preclude the national courts from awarding compensation of a small amount provided that such compensation fully offsets that damage.
direction_justification: Confirms no de minimis threshold (pro-data subject) but permits minimal/symbolic awards for minor damage (pro-controller).

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen
core_holding: Identity theft requires actual misuse of identity by a third party, but compensation for data theft is not limited to cases of proven identity theft.
semantic_quote: The concepts of identity 'theft' and 'fraud' are interchangeable and no distinction can be drawn between them.
systematic_quote: Among the various concepts set out in the lists in recitals 75 and 85 of the GDPR, 'loss of control' or the inability 'to exercise control' over personal data are distinguished from identity 'theft' or 'fraud'.
teleological_quote: However, it must be stated, in that regard, that compensation for non-material damage caused by the theft of personal data, pursuant to Article 82(1) of the GDPR, cannot be limited to cases where it is shown that that data theft subsequently gave rise to identity theft or fraud.
direction_justification: Clarifies that compensation is available for data theft even without proven identity theft or fraud, lowering the burden for claimants.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Arabadjiev;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;N. Jääskinen;I. Ziemele;J. Passer;M. Ilešič;J.-C. Bonichot;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: Online publication of declarations of private interests is precluded where it includes name-specific data about declarant's spouse, close relatives, or transactions exceeding EUR 3000.
semantic_quote: Under Article 7(e) of Directive 95/46 and point (e) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, which are mentioned by the referring court in its first question, processing that is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller is lawful.
systematic_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR specifies, in respect of those two situations where processing is lawful, that the processing must be based on EU law or on Member State law to which the controller is subject, and that that legal basis must meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.
teleological_quote: In accordance with Article 1(1) of Directive 95/46, read in conjunction with recital 10 thereof, and Article 1(2) of the GDPR, read in conjunction with recitals 4 and 10 thereof, that directive and that regulation have the objective in particular of ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons with respect to the processing of personal data.
direction_justification: Court restricts scope of permissible online publication of personal data, requiring proportionality assessment that favors privacy over transparency.
other_rights: transparency;prevention of corruption;public interest in good governance

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Arabadjiev;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;N. Jääskinen;I. Ziemele;J. Passer;M. Ilešič;J.-C. Bonichot;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: Personal data liable to indirectly reveal sexual orientation constitutes processing of special categories of personal data under Article 9(1) GDPR.
semantic_quote: Article 8(1) of Directive 95/46 states that Member States are to prohibit the processing of personal data 'revealing' racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, and the processing of data 'concerning' health or sex life.
systematic_quote: Such an interpretation, which would result in a distinction being drawn according to the type of sensitive data at issue, would not, however, be consistent with a contextual analysis of those provisions, in particular with Article 4(15) of the GDPR.
teleological_quote: Furthermore, a wide interpretation of the terms 'special categories of personal data' and 'sensitive data' is confirmed by the objective of Directive 95/46 and the GDPR, noted in paragraph 61 of the present judgment, which is to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular of their private life, with respect to the processing of personal data concerning them.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of special categories to include indirect revelation of sensitive data expands protection for data subjects.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Directive 2017/1132 does not oblige Member States to permit disclosure of personal data in company constitutive instruments beyond minimum required data.
semantic_quote: Having regard in particular to the repeated use of the term 'translations' in Article 21(2) of Directive 2017/1132, it is apparent from the wording of that provision that it concerns the voluntary disclosure of translations of the documents and particulars referred to in Article 14 of that directive into an official language of the European Union and, therefore, only the language of in which those documents and particulars are published.
systematic_quote: As regards the context of Article 21(2) of Directive 2017/1132, the title of that article, which refers to the 'Language of disclosure and translation of documents and particulars to be disclosed', as well as the other paragraphs of that article, support the interpretation referred to in paragraph 55 of this judgment.
teleological_quote: Last, the interpretation referred to in paragraph 55 of this judgment is confirmed by recital 12 thereof, according to which cross-border access to company information should be facilitated by allowing, in addition to compulsory disclosure made in one of the languages permitted in the company's Member State, the voluntary registration in additional languages of the required documents and particulars.
direction_justification: This holding clarifies scope of EU directive without expanding or restricting data subject rights.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: The authority maintaining the commercial register is both a recipient and controller of personal data it publishes, even for non-required data.
semantic_quote: Under Article 4(7) of the GDPR, the concept of 'controller' covers natural or legal persons, public authorities, agencies or other bodies which, alone or jointly with others, determine the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
systematic_quote: It follows from Article 2(d) that the controller is the entity which 'determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data'.
teleological_quote: In that regard, it should be borne in mind that, according to the case-law of the Court, that provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition ensures commercial register authority bears GDPR obligations for all published data.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: A Member State cannot refuse erasure requests for non-required personal data solely because redacted document copies were not provided by the applicant.
semantic_quote: In accordance with Article 17(1) of the GDPR, the data subject has the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay and the controller has the obligation to erase those personal data without undue delay where one of the grounds set out in that provision applies.
systematic_quote: In accordance with Article 161 of that directive, the processing of personal data carried out in the context of that directive must fully satisfy the requirements arising from the GDPR.
teleological_quote: It is thus for the Member States, in the context of the implementation of the obligations imposed by that directive, to ensure that the objectives of legal certainty and protection of the interests of third parties pursued by that directive and recalled in paragraph 77 of the present judgment, are reconciled with the rights enshrined in the GDPR and the fundamental right to the protection of personal data, by striking a fair balance between those objectives and those rights.
direction_justification: Data subjects can obtain erasure of non-required personal data from commercial registers without needing third-party cooperation.
other_rights: legal certainty;protection of third-party interests

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: A handwritten signature of a natural person constitutes personal data under the GDPR.
semantic_quote: That provision lays down that personal data means 'any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person' and specifies that 'an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person'.
teleological_quote: In that connection, the Court has already held that the use of the expression 'any information' in the definition of the concept of 'personal data' in that provision reflects the aim of the EU legislature to assign a wide scope to that concept, which potentially encompasses all kinds of information, not only objective but also subjective, in the form of opinions and assessments, provided that it 'relates' to the data subject.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data to include handwritten signatures expands scope of GDPR protection.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Loss of control over personal data for a limited period may constitute compensable non-material damage if the data subject proves actual damage occurred.
semantic_quote: That provision states that 'any person who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of [the GDPR] shall have the right to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered'.
teleological_quote: It is apparent not only from the wording of Article 82(1) of the GDPR, read in the light of recitals 85 and 146 thereof – which encourage the acceptance of a broad interpretation of the concept of 'non-material damage', within the meaning of that first provision – but also from the objective of ensuring a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data – which is referred to by the regulation – that the fear experienced by a data subject with regard to a possible misuse of his or her personal data by third parties as a result of an infringement of that regulation is capable, in itself, of constituting 'non-material damage', within the meaning of Article 82(1).
direction_justification: Broad concept of damage favors data subjects but requirement to prove actual damage creates a threshold that may limit recovery.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: A non-binding supervisory authority opinion cannot exempt the controller from liability under Article 82(3) GDPR.
semantic_quote: Article 82(3) of the GDPR, for its part, states that a controller is to be exempt from liability under paragraph 2 if it proves that it is not in any way responsible for the event giving rise to the damage.
systematic_quote: Among the powers listed in Article 58(3) of the GDPR is included, in point (b) of that provision, the power 'to issue, on its own initiative or on request, opinions to the national parliament, the Member State government or, in accordance with Member State law, to other institutions and bodies as well as to the public on any issue related to the protection of personal data'.
teleological_quote: Such an interpretation of Article 82(3) is also consistent with the objectives pursued by the GDPR of ensuring a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data and of ensuring effective compensation for the damage that they may suffer as a result of processing of those data that infringes that regulation.
direction_justification: Controllers cannot escape liability by relying on DPA opinions, maintaining strong accountability standards.

judges: K. Lenaerts;T. von Danwitz;A. Kumin;N. Jääskinen;I. Ziemele
core_holding: In automated decision-making including profiling, data subjects may require controllers to explain in a concise, transparent, and intelligible form the procedure and principles actually applied to their personal data.
semantic_quote: The generally accepted meanings of the concept of 'meaningful information' under that provision, in the various language versions of that provision, differ; some, like the French-language version, favour the functionality ('nuttige' in Dutch, 'úteis' in Portuguese) or the relevance ('pertinente' in Romanian) of the information to be provided, while others place greater emphasis on the importance of that information ('significativa' in Spanish and 'istotne' in Polish).
systematic_quote: Having regard to the fact that the concept of 'meaningful information about the logic involved' also appears in Article 13(2)(f) and Article 14(2)(g) of the GDPR, the Court has already held that, in the case of automated decision-making, within the meaning of Article 22(1) of that regulation, the right of access to such information enshrined in Article 15(1)(h) thereof forms a whole with the additional information obligations imposed on the controller under Article 13(2)(f) and Article 14(2)(g) of the GDPR.
teleological_quote: That right of access is necessary to enable the data subject to exercise, depending on the circumstances, his or her right to rectification, right to erasure ('right to be forgotten') or right to restriction of processing, conferred, respectively, by Articles 16, 17 and 18 of the GDPR, as well as the data subject's right to object to his or her personal data being processed, laid down in Article 21 of the GDPR, right of action and right to compensation, laid down in Articles 79 and 82 of the GDPR, respectively.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of meaningful information requires controllers to explain procedure and principles of automated processing, enhancing data subject understanding and ability to exercise rights.

judges: K. Lenaerts;T. von Danwitz;A. Kumin;N. Jääskinen;I. Ziemele
core_holding: When information under Article 15(1)(h) contains third-party data or trade secrets, the controller must provide it to the supervisory authority or court to balance competing interests.
systematic_quote: Moreover, recital 63 of that regulation states that the right for any data subject to have access to personal data which have been collected concerning him or her should not adversely affect the rights or freedoms of others, including trade secrets or intellectual property and in particular the copyright protecting the software.
teleological_quote: In the event of conflict between, on the one hand, exercising the right of full and complete access to personal data and, on the other hand, the rights or freedoms of others, a balance will have to be struck between the rights and freedoms in question.
direction_justification: Balances data subject access rights against trade secrets and third-party rights, requiring case-by-case assessment rather than blanket exclusions; invalidates Austrian provision creating automatic exception.
other_rights: trade secrets;rights and freedoms of third parties

judges: E. Regan;D. Gratsias;M. Ilešič;I. Jarukaitis;Z. Csehi
core_holding: Processing of biometric and genetic data by police is authorized by Member State law if that law contains a sufficiently clear and precise legal basis, even if it incorrectly references the GDPR instead of Directive 2016/680.
semantic_quote: It follows from the case-law recalled in the previous paragraph of the present judgment that there can be no uncertainty as to the provisions of EU law pursuant to which national law may authorise processing of biometric and genetic data, such as the processing at issue in the main proceedings, or as to the applicable conditions governing that authorisation.
systematic_quote: Whilst the national legislature has the option to provide, in the same legislative instrument, for the processing of personal data for purposes covered by Directive 2016/680 and for other purposes covered by the GDPR, it has, on the other hand, the obligation, in accordance with the requirements set out in the previous paragraph of the present judgment, to make sure that there is no ambiguity as to the applicability of one or other of those two EU acts to the collection of biometric and genetic data.
teleological_quote: Data subjects and the courts having jurisdiction must be in a position to be able to determine precisely, in particular, the conditions under which that processing may take place and the purposes which it may lawfully pursue.
direction_justification: The holding clarifies technical transposition requirements without expanding or restricting substantive data protection rights.

judges: E. Regan;D. Gratsias;M. Ilešič;I. Jarukaitis;Z. Csehi
core_holding: National legislation may allow courts to authorize compulsory collection of biometric and genetic data from accused persons without assessing evidence, provided effective judicial review is subsequently guaranteed.
semantic_quote: The existence of sufficient items of evidence pointing to a person's guilt constitutes, in principle, a serious ground for believing that he or she has committed the offence at issue.
systematic_quote: Article 6 of Directive 2016/680 obliges the Member States to provide for the controller, 'where applicable and as far as possible', to make a clear distinction between personal data of different categories of data subjects.
teleological_quote: Such collection may contribute to the objective set out in recital 27 of Directive 2016/680, which states that, for the prevention, investigation and prosecution of criminal offences, it is necessary for competent authorities to process personal data collected in the context of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of specific criminal offences beyond that context in order to develop an understanding of criminal activities and to make links between different criminal offences detected.
direction_justification: The holding permits compulsory data collection without full judicial review at the initial stage, favoring law enforcement operational needs over immediate data subject protection.
other_rights: presumption of innocence;right to effective judicial protection

judges: E. Regan;D. Gratsias;M. Ilešič;I. Jarukaitis;Z. Csehi
core_holding: National legislation providing for systematic collection of biometric and genetic data of all persons accused of intentional public prosecution offences is precluded without verification that collection is strictly necessary.
semantic_quote: As is set out in Article 10 of Directive 2016/680, the requirement that the processing of such data be allowed 'only where strictly necessary' must be interpreted as establishing strengthened conditions for lawful processing of sensitive data.
systematic_quote: The specific requirements of Article 10 of Directive 2016/680 constitute a special form of implementation, applicable to certain categories of data, of the principles set out in Articles 4 and 8 of that directive, which must be observed by any data processing falling within the directive's scope.
teleological_quote: The purpose of that article is to ensure enhanced protection with regard to that processing, which, because of the particular sensitivity of the data at issue and the context in which they are processed, is liable, as is apparent from recital 37 of the directive, to create significant risks to fundamental rights and freedoms.
direction_justification: The holding prohibits systematic blanket collection of sensitive biometric and genetic data, requiring individualized necessity assessment and limiting law enforcement discretion.
other_rights: right to respect for private life;right to protection of personal data

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: An official journal may be classified as a controller of personal data in published documents even without legal personality, where national law determines the purposes and means of processing.
semantic_quote: Under point 7 of Article 4 of the GDPR, the concept of 'controller' covers natural or legal persons, public authorities, agencies or other bodies which, alone or jointly with others, determine the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
systematic_quote: It is apparent from the clear wording of that provision that a controller may be not only a natural or legal person, but also a public authority, an agency or a body, and such entities do not necessarily have legal personality under national law.
teleological_quote: In that regard, it should be borne in mind that, according to the case-law of the Court, that provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition to include official journals ensures data subjects can exercise their rights against the publishing entity.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: The official journal is solely responsible for compliance with Article 5(1) principles for its processing operations unless national law establishes joint responsibility with other entities in the processing chain.
semantic_quote: Under Article 5(2) of the GDPR, the controller is to be responsible for compliance with the principles laid down in the form of obligations in paragraph 1 of that article and must be able to demonstrate compliance with those principles.
systematic_quote: It is thus apparent from that provision that the respective responsibilities of joint controllers of personal data do not necessarily depend on the existence of an arrangement between the various controllers, but may stem from national law.
teleological_quote: In that regard, it should be borne in mind that, according to the case-law of the Court, that provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.
direction_justification: The holding clarifies allocation of responsibility without expanding or restricting either controller obligations or data subject rights.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;N. Jääskinen;J.-C. Bonichot;M. Safjan
core_holding: Courts making documents containing personal data available to journalists for reporting falls within their judicial capacity, excluding DPA supervisory competence.
semantic_quote: It is apparent from Article 55 of Regulation 2016/679 that the purpose of that article is to define competence in matters of supervision of the processing of personal data and, in particular, to delimit the competence vested in the national supervisory authority.
systematic_quote: Regulation 2016/679 can be distinguished in that regard from Directive 2003/4/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 28 January 2003 on public access to environmental information and repealing Council Directive 90/313/EEC, which does not apply to courts and tribunals.
teleological_quote: Recital 20 of Regulation 2016/679, in the light of which that Article 55(3) must be read, states that it should be possible to entrust supervision of processing operations carried out by the courts 'acting in their judicial capacity' to specific bodies within the judicial system of the Member State concerned rather than to the supervisory authority under the authority of that Member State, in order to 'safeguard the independence of the judiciary in the performance of its judicial tasks, including decision-making'.
direction_justification: Court interprets judicial capacity exception broadly to exclude DPA oversight, limiting data subjects' ability to complain to supervisory authority about court data processing.
other_rights: judicial independence;open justice/transparency

judges: K. Lenaerts;T. von Danwitz;M.L. Arastey Sahún;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: A national authority keeping a public register must rectify personal data relating to gender identity where those data are inaccurate under the accuracy principle.
semantic_quote: Under Article 16 of the GDPR, the data subject has the right to obtain from the controller without undue delay the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning him or her.
systematic_quote: That provision gives specific expression to the fundamental right enshrined in the second sentence of Article 8(2) of the Charter, according to which everyone has the right of access to data which have been collected concerning him or her, and the right to have them rectified.
teleological_quote: The objective pursued by that regulation, as is set out in Article 1 thereof and in recitals 1 and 10 thereof, consists, inter alia, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of rectification right prevents Member States from limiting gender identity rectification through absence of national procedures.
other_rights: right to integrity of the person;right to respect for private life

judges: K. Lenaerts;T. von Danwitz;M.L. Arastey Sahún;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Member States cannot require proof of gender reassignment surgery as condition for exercising the right to rectification of gender identity data in public registers.
semantic_quote: Article 16 of the GDPR does not specify which evidence may be required by a controller in order to establish the inaccuracy of the personal data which a natural person seeks to have rectified.
systematic_quote: Article 23(1) of the GDPR provides that EU or Member State law to which the data controller or processor is subject may restrict by way of a legislative measure the scope of the obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22.
teleological_quote: Such an administrative practice undermines the essence of the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Charter and, in particular, the essence of the right to the integrity of the person and the right to respect for private life, referred to in Articles 3 and 7 of the Charter respectively.
direction_justification: Prohibits surgery requirement for gender identity rectification, protecting transgender persons from disproportionate evidentiary burdens.
other_rights: right to integrity of the person;right to respect for private life

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;M. Safjan;L.S. Rossi;D. Gratsias;M.L. Arastey Sahún;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;M. Gavalec;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: A national competition authority may find that a dominant undertaking's data processing terms are inconsistent with the GDPR when necessary to establish abuse of dominance, subject to sincere cooperation with data protection supervisory authorities.
semantic_quote: Neither the GDPR nor any other instrument of EU law provides for specific rules on cooperation between a national competition authority and the relevant national supervisory authorities concerned or the lead supervisory authority.
systematic_quote: The supervisory authorities, on the one hand, and the national competition authorities, on the other, perform different functions and pursue their own objectives and tasks.
teleological_quote: Excluding the rules on the protection of personal data from the legal framework to be taken into consideration by the competition authorities when examining an abuse of a dominant position would disregard the reality of this economic development and would be liable to undermine the effectiveness of competition law within the European Union.
direction_justification: The holding addresses institutional competence allocation between competition and data protection authorities, not substantive rights of data subjects or controllers.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;M. Safjan;L.S. Rossi;D. Gratsias;M.L. Arastey Sahún;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;M. Gavalec;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: Collection and linking of off-platform data revealing sensitive categories constitutes prohibited processing of special categories of personal data, regardless of whether the revealed information concerns the user or another person.
semantic_quote: Article 9(1) of the GDPR lays down the principle that the processing of special categories of personal data listed therein is prohibited.
systematic_quote: Recital 51 of the GDPR states that personal data which are, by their nature, particularly sensitive in relation to fundamental rights and freedoms merit specific protection as the context of their processing could create significant risks to the fundamental rights and freedoms.
teleological_quote: In view of the significant risks to the fundamental freedoms and fundamental rights of data subjects arising from any processing of personal data falling within the categories referred to in Article 9(1) of the GDPR, the objective thereof is to prohibit such processing, irrespective of its stated purpose.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of special categories to include data that can reveal sensitive information extends protection to users whose browsing behavior may reveal health, political, or sexual orientation data.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;M. Safjan;L.S. Rossi;D. Gratsias;M.L. Arastey Sahún;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;M. Gavalec;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: Merely visiting websites does not constitute manifestly making data public; entering information or clicking buttons only does so where the user explicitly chose to make data accessible to an unlimited number of persons.
semantic_quote: Under that provision, the fundamental prohibition of any processing of special categories of personal data, established in Article 9(1) of the GDPR, does not apply in the circumstance where the processing relates to personal data which are 'manifestly made public by the data subject'.
teleological_quote: In so far as it provides for an exception to the principle that the processing of special categories of personal data is prohibited, Article 9(2) of the GDPR must be interpreted strictly.
direction_justification: Narrow interpretation of the manifestly made public exception prevents social networks from claiming user browsing or interaction implies public disclosure of sensitive data.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;M. Safjan;L.S. Rossi;D. Gratsias;M.L. Arastey Sahún;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;M. Gavalec;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: Processing of off-platform data is necessary for contract performance only if objectively indispensable for a purpose integral to the contractual obligation, such that the contract's main subject matter cannot be achieved without it.
semantic_quote: Under point (b) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, that provision provides that processing of personal data is lawful if it is 'necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party or in order to take steps at the request of the data subject prior to entering into a contract'.
systematic_quote: The fact that such processing may be referred to in the contract or may be merely useful for the performance of the contract is, in itself, irrelevant in that regard.
teleological_quote: The decisive factor for the purposes of applying the justification set out in point (b) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR is rather that the processing of personal data by the controller must be essential for the proper performance of the contract concluded between the controller and the data subject.
direction_justification: Strict interpretation of contract necessity prevents social networks from bundling unnecessary data processing into service contracts and claiming contractual basis.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;M. Safjan;L.S. Rossi;D. Gratsias;M.L. Arastey Sahún;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;M. Gavalec;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: Processing for legitimate interests requires informing users of the specific interest pursued, strict necessity, and a balancing test where users' interests and fundamental rights do not override the controller's legitimate interest.
semantic_quote: That provision provides that the processing of personal data is lawful only if it is 'necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data, in particular where the data subject is a child'.
systematic_quote: The condition relating to the need for processing must be examined in conjunction with the 'data minimisation' principle enshrined in Article 5(1)(c) of the GDPR.
teleological_quote: In those circumstances, it must be held that the interests and fundamental rights of such a user override the interest of that operator in such personalised advertising by which it finances its activity, with the result that the processing by that operator for such purposes cannot fall within the scope of point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR.
direction_justification: Users' fundamental rights and reasonable expectations override controller's advertising interests; extensive tracking creates a feeling of continuous surveillance that overrides commercial interests.
other_rights: right to respect for private life;right to protection of personal data

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;M. Safjan;L.S. Rossi;D. Gratsias;M.L. Arastey Sahún;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;M. Gavalec;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: Processing for legal obligation compliance requires actual necessity pursuant to EU or Member State law meeting a public interest objective, proportionality to the legitimate aim, and strict necessity in the processing carried out.
semantic_quote: Under point (c), processing of personal data is lawful if it is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject.
systematic_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR specifies, inter alia, in respect of those two situations in which processing is lawful, that the processing must be based on EU law or on Member State law to which the controller is subject.
teleological_quote: That legal basis must meet an objective of public interest and be proportionate to the legitimate aim pursued.
direction_justification: The holding provides interpretive guidance on the legal obligation basis without decisively expanding or limiting its scope.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;M. Safjan;L.S. Rossi;D. Gratsias;M.L. Arastey Sahún;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;M. Gavalec;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: A social network operator cannot in principle rely on vital interests or public interest/official authority bases to justify off-platform data collection given its essentially commercial nature.
semantic_quote: That provision provides that the processing of personal data is lawful where it is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or of another natural person.
systematic_quote: As can be seen from recital 46 of that regulation, that provision covers the specific situation in which the processing of personal data is necessary to protect an interest which is essential for the life of the data subject or that of another natural person.
teleological_quote: It follows from those examples and from the strict interpretation to be given to point (d) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR that, in view of the nature of the services provided by the operator of an online social network, such an operator, whose activity is essentially economic and commercial in nature, cannot rely on the protection of an interest which is essential for the life of its users or of another person in order to justify, absolutely and in a purely abstract and preventive manner, the lawfulness of data processing.
direction_justification: Limiting commercial entities from invoking vital interests or public interest bases prevents abuse of these narrow exceptions by private platforms.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Prechal;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;M. Safjan;L.S. Rossi;D. Gratsias;M.L. Arastey Sahún;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;M. Gavalec;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei
core_holding: A dominant position does not per se preclude valid consent, but is an important factor in assessing whether consent was freely given, particularly regarding imbalance of power and bundling of unnecessary processing.
semantic_quote: Article 4(11) of the GDPR, for its part, defines 'consent' as meaning 'any freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of the data subject's wishes by which he or she, by a statement or by a clear affirmative action, signifies agreement to the processing of personal data relating to him or her'.
systematic_quote: Article 7(4) of the GDPR provides that when assessing whether consent is freely given, utmost account must be taken of whether, inter alia, the performance of a contract, including the provision of a service, is conditional on consent to the processing of personal data that is not necessary for the performance of that contract.
teleological_quote: Such a circumstance must be taken into consideration in assessing whether the user of that network has validly and, in particular, freely given consent, since that circumstance is liable to affect the freedom of choice of that user, who might be unable to refuse or withdraw consent without detriment.
direction_justification: Dominant position does not automatically invalidate consent (pro-controller), but must be considered as important factor affecting freedom of choice and requires option to refuse without detriment (pro-data subject).

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: A supervisory authority decision on a complaint is subject to full judicial review, not merely procedural review of whether the complaint was handled.
semantic_quote: That provision provides that, without prejudice to any other administrative or non-judicial remedy, each natural or legal person is to have the right to an effective judicial remedy against a legally binding decision of a supervisory authority concerning them.
systematic_quote: It is important to note that, in accordance with Article 8(3) of the Charter and Article 51(1) and Article 57(1)(a) of the GDPR, the national supervisory authorities are responsible for monitoring compliance with the EU rules concerning the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.
teleological_quote: If Article 78(1) of that regulation were to be interpreted as meaning that the judicial review referred to therein is limited to verifying whether the supervisory authority has handled the complaint, investigated the subject matter of the complaint to the extent appropriate and informed the complainant of the outcome of the investigation, the attainment of the objectives and the pursuit of the purpose of the regulation would necessarily be compromised.
direction_justification: Establishes full judicial review of DPA decisions, strengthening data subject remedies against inadequate supervisory authority responses.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Credit agencies cannot retain insolvency discharge data beyond the public register retention period as this fails the legitimate interest balancing test.
semantic_quote: Under that provision, the processing of personal data is lawful only if and to the extent that it is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data.
systematic_quote: In that context, it should also be recalled that the condition relating to the need for processing must be examined in conjunction with the 'data minimisation' principle enshrined in Article 5(1)(c) of the GDPR, in accordance with which personal data must be 'adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed'.
teleological_quote: Moreover, as the Advocate General observed in point 75 of his Opinion, the discharge from remaining debts is intended to allow the person who benefits from it to re-enter economic life and is therefore generally of existential importance to that person.
direction_justification: Limits credit agency data retention to public register period, restricting controller processing and prioritizing data subject rehabilitation interests.
other_rights: right to respect for private life;right to protection of personal data

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Data subjects have the right to erasure when they object to processing and the controller cannot demonstrate overriding legitimate grounds.
semantic_quote: That provision establishes the right to erasure of personal data where the data subject objects to the processing pursuant to Article 21(1) of the GDPR and there are no 'overriding legitimate grounds for the processing'.
systematic_quote: It follows from a combined reading of those provisions that the data subject enjoys a right to object to processing and a right to erasure, unless there are overriding legitimate grounds which take precedence over the interests and rights and freedoms of that person within the meaning of Article 21(1) of the GDPR, which it is for the controller to demonstrate.
direction_justification: Confirms erasure right when data subject objects and places burden on controller to demonstrate overriding legitimate grounds.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Controllers must erase unlawfully processed personal data as soon as possible without undue delay.
semantic_quote: Under Article 17(1)(d) of the GDPR, to which the referring court refers, the data subject has the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning him or her without undue delay and the controller has the obligation to erase personal data without undue delay where the personal data have been unlawfully processed.
direction_justification: Affirms immediate erasure obligation for unlawfully processed data, strengthening data subject remedies.

judges: K. Jürimäe;M.L. Arastey Sahún;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Article 6(3) and (4) GDPR applies to the production in civil court proceedings of documents containing personal data originally collected for other purposes such as tax inspection.
semantic_quote: According to Article 4(2) of that regulation, the definition of 'processing' of personal data includes any operation which is performed on personal data, whether or not by automated means, such as collection, recording, use, disclosure by transmission, dissemination or otherwise making available.
systematic_quote: The combined provisions of Article 6(1)(e) of the GDPR and Article 6(3) thereof therefore require there to be a legal basis – national in particular – which serves as a basis for the processing of personal data by the relevant controllers acting in the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority, such as those performed by courts acting in their judicial capacity.
teleological_quote: Those objectives include, in accordance with Article 23(1)(f) of that regulation, 'the protection of judicial independence and judicial proceedings', which, as the European Commission noted in its written observations, must be understood as referring to the protection of the administration of justice from internal or external interference, but also to the proper administration of justice.
direction_justification: The holding clarifies the scope of GDPR application to civil proceedings without expanding or restricting rights of either party.

judges: K. Jürimäe;M.L. Arastey Sahún;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: When ordering document production containing personal data, national courts must balance data subject interests against other interests, applying proportionality and data minimisation principles.
semantic_quote: According to that data minimisation principle, personal data must be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.
systematic_quote: Any processing of personal data must, subject to the derogations permitted in Article 23 thereof, observe the principles governing the processing of personal data and the rights of the person concerned set out, respectively, in Chapters II and III of that regulation.
teleological_quote: However, as recital 4 of the GDPR states, the right to the protection of personal data is not an absolute right, but must be considered in relation to its function in society and be balanced, in accordance with the principle of proportionality, against other fundamental rights, such as the right to effective judicial protection, guaranteed in Article 47 of the Charter.
direction_justification: Requires courts to actively consider data subject interests and apply data minimisation, including pseudonymisation and access restrictions, when ordering document production.
other_rights: right to effective judicial protection;right to a fair trial

judges: A. Prechal;L.S. Rossi;J. Malenovský;F. Biltgen;N. Wahl
core_holding: A petitions committee of a federated state parliament that determines purposes and means of processing personal data is a controller under the GDPR.
semantic_quote: Article 4(7) of that regulation defines the 'controller' as being the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
systematic_quote: Since Article 2(2)(a) of that regulation constitutes an exception to the very wide definition of the scope of that regulation set out in Article 2(1) of that regulation, Article 2(2)(a) must be interpreted restrictively.
teleological_quote: That applies a fortiori with respect to Regulation 2016/679, which is based on Article 16 TFEU, which states that the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union are to lay down the rules relating to the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by, in particular, Member States when carrying out activities which fall within the scope of Union law, and the rules relating to the free movement of such data.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of controller definition to include parliamentary committees expands GDPR scope and enables data subject access rights.

judges: K. Jürimäe;M. Safjan;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: The mere infringement of GDPR provisions is not sufficient to confer a right to compensation; actual damage must be proven.
semantic_quote: It is clear from the wording of that provision that the existence of 'damage' which has been 'suffered' constitutes one of the conditions for the right to compensation laid down in that provision, as does the existence of an infringement of the GDPR and of a causal link between that damage and that infringement, those three conditions being cumulative.
systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
direction_justification: Requires proof of actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, limiting compensation claims.

judges: K. Jürimäe;M. Safjan;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: National rules cannot make compensation for non-material damage conditional on the damage reaching a certain threshold of seriousness.
semantic_quote: Article 82 of that regulation confines itself to expressly stating that not only 'material damage' but also 'non-material damage' may give rise to a right to compensation, without any reference being made to any threshold of seriousness.
systematic_quote: The third sentence of recital 146 of the GDPR states that 'the concept of damage should be broadly interpreted in the light of the case-law of the Court of Justice in a manner which fully reflects the objectives of this Regulation'.
teleological_quote: It would be contrary to that broad conception of 'damage', favoured by the EU legislature, if that concept were limited solely to damage of a certain degree of seriousness.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of damage concept prevents Member States from imposing seriousness thresholds that would limit compensation claims.

judges: K. Jürimäe;M. Safjan;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: National courts apply domestic rules to determine damages amounts, subject to principles of equivalence and effectiveness ensuring full and effective compensation.
systematic_quote: In the absence of EU rules on the matter, it is for the national legal order of each Member State to establish procedural rules for actions intended to safeguard the rights of individuals, in accordance with the principle of procedural autonomy.
teleological_quote: In that regard, in view of the compensatory function of the right to compensation under Article 82 of the GDPR, as the Advocate General pointed out, in essence, in points 39, 49 and 52 of his Opinion, financial compensation based on that provision must be regarded as 'full and effective' if it allows the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in its entirety, without there being any need, for the purposes of such compensation for the damage in its entirety, to require the payment of punitive damages.
direction_justification: Defers to national law on quantum but requires full and effective compensation, balancing procedural autonomy with data subject protection.

judges: N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Processing of personal data in the context of organizing elections in a Member State falls within the scope of the GDPR and is not excluded by Article 2(2)(a).
semantic_quote: It should be pointed out that that exception to the applicability of the GDPR must, like the other exceptions laid down in Article 2(2), be interpreted strictly.
systematic_quote: It should be noted that Article 2(2)(a) of the GDPR is to be read in conjunction with Article 2(2)(b) thereof and recital 16, which states that that regulation does not apply to the processing of personal data in the context of 'activities which fall outside the scope of Union law, such as activities concerning national security' and 'activities in relation to the common foreign and security policy of the Union'.
teleological_quote: Article 2(2)(a) of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 16 thereof, is designed solely to exclude from the scope of that regulation the processing of personal data carried out by State authorities in the course of an activity which is intended to safeguard national security or of an activity which can be classified in the same category.
