direction_justification: Requires proof of damage (pro-controller) but rejects severity threshold (pro-data subject).

judges: K. Jürimäe;K. Lenaerts;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Fear of personal data disclosure to third parties can constitute compensable non-material damage if the fear and its negative consequences are duly proven.
semantic_quote: In the absence of any reference in Article 82(1) of the GDPR to the domestic law of the Member States, the concept of 'non-material damage', within the meaning of that provision, must be given an autonomous and uniform definition specific to EU law.
teleological_quote: The Court has held that it is apparent not only from the wording of Article 82(1) of the GDPR, read in the light of recitals 85 and 146 of that regulation, which encourage the acceptance of a broad interpretation of the concept of 'non-material damage' within the meaning of that first provision, but also the objective of ensuring a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage allows compensation for fear even without proving actual disclosure.

judges: K. Jürimäe;K. Lenaerts;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Article 83 administrative fine criteria do not apply to compensation assessment, and Article 82 compensation has no dissuasive or punitive function.
semantic_quote: While Article 83 of that regulation determines the 'general conditions for imposing administrative fines', Article 82 of that regulation governs the 'right to compensation and liability'.
systematic_quote: Thus, in the light of the differences in wording and purpose existing between Article 82 of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 146 thereof, and Article 83 of that regulation, read in the light of recital 148 thereof, it cannot be found that the assessment criteria specifically set out in Article 83 are applicable mutatis mutandis in the context of Article 82.
teleological_quote: In view of the compensatory function of the right to compensation under Article 82 of the GDPR, as set out in the sixth sentence of recital 146 of that regulation, financial compensation based on that article must be regarded as 'full and effective' if it allows the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in its entirety.
direction_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage suffered without punitive or dissuasive elements, reducing potential liability.

judges: K. Jürimäe;K. Lenaerts;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Simultaneous infringements of national data protection provisions not specifying GDPR rules are irrelevant for determining compensation under Article 82(1).
semantic_quote: However, the fact that such data processing was also carried out in breach of provisions of national law relating to the protection of personal data but not intended to specify the rules of that regulation, is not a relevant factor for the purposes of assessing the damages awarded on the basis of Article 82(1) of the GDPR.
systematic_quote: The infringement of such national provisions is not covered by Article 82(1) of that regulation, read in conjunction with recital 146 thereof.
direction_justification: Limits scope of compensation to GDPR-specific infringements, excluding broader national law violations from increasing damages.

judges: E. Regan;M. Ilešič;E. Juhász;C. Lycourgos;I. Jarukaitis
core_holding: Uploading pieces of a media file on a peer-to-peer network constitutes making available to the public even when automatic, provided the user consented to the software.
semantic_quote: In order for there to be an 'act of communication', and consequently, an act of making available, it is sufficient, in the final analysis, that a work is made available to a public in such a way that the persons comprising that public may access it, from wherever and whenever they individually choose, irrespective of whether or not they avail themselves of that opportunity.
systematic_quote: Since the EU legislature did not express a different intention, the expression 'making available to the public', used in Article 3(1) of Directive 2001/29 as a form of authors' exclusive right to authorise or prohibit any 'communication to the public', and the identical expression in Article 3(2) of that directive, designating an exclusive right belonging to the holders of related rights, must be interpreted as having the same meaning.
teleological_quote: Disregard of that balance would, moreover, undermine the principal objective of Directive 2001/29, which, as is apparent from recitals 4, 9 and 10 thereof, is to establish a high level of protection for rightholders, enabling rightholders to obtain an appropriate reward for the use of their protected works or other subject matter, in particular when they are made available to the public.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of making available to the public favors intellectual property rightholders by enabling enforcement against peer-to-peer network users.
other_rights: intellectual property;freedom of expression and information

judges: E. Regan;M. Ilešič;E. Juhász;C. Lycourgos;I. Jarukaitis
core_holding: A contractual IP rights holder who only claims damages from infringers may benefit from Directive 2004/48 measures unless the request is abusive, unjustified, or disproportionate.
semantic_quote: Those categories include, first, holders of intellectual property rights, secondly, all the other persons authorised to use those rights, in particular licensees, thirdly, intellectual property collective rights management bodies which are regularly recognised as having a right to represent holders of intellectual property rights, and, fourth, professional defence bodies which are regularly recognised as having a right to represent holders of intellectual property rights.
systematic_quote: Unlike the holders of intellectual property rights referred to in Article 4(a) of Directive 2004/48, in accordance with recital 18 of that directive, the three categories of persons referred to in Article 4(b) to (d) thereof must also have a direct interest in the defence of those rights and the right to be a party to legal proceedings in so far as permitted by, and in accordance with, the applicable legislation.
teleological_quote: Such an exclusion runs counter to the general objective of Directive 2004/48, which is, as is clear from recital 10 thereof, to ensure a high level of protection of intellectual property in the internal market.
direction_justification: Rights holder can claim damages but court must assess for abuse; request must be justified and proportionate, balancing enforcement with safeguards.
other_rights: intellectual property

judges: E. Regan;M. Ilešič;E. Juhász;C. Lycourgos;I. Jarukaitis
core_holding: GDPR Article 6(1)(f) with ePrivacy Directive Article 15(1) does not preclude systematic IP address recording or disclosure for civil claims if justified, proportionate, and legally based.
semantic_quote: Under point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of Regulation 2016/679, the processing of personal data is lawful only if it is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or by a third party, except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data, in particular where the data subject is a child.
systematic_quote: As is apparent from Article 1(2) of Directive 2002/58, read in conjunction with Article 94(2) of Regulation 2016/679, the provisions of that directive specify and complement that regulation in order to harmonise the national provisions necessary to ensure, in particular, an equivalent level of protection of fundamental rights and freedoms, and in particular the right to privacy, as regards the processing of personal data in the electronic communications sector.
teleological_quote: The fact that Article 23(1)(j) of that regulation now expressly refers to the enforcement of claims under civil law must be interpreted as expressing the intention of the EU legislature to confirm the case-law of the Court according to which the protection of the right to property and situations in which authors seek to obtain such protection in civil proceedings have never been excluded from the scope of Article 15(1) of Directive 2002/58.
direction_justification: Allows IP address collection and disclosure for IP enforcement but requires justification, proportionality, non-abuse, and national legal basis, balancing both interests.
other_rights: intellectual property;right to property;right to effective remedy

judges: C. Lycourgos;O. Spineanu-Matei;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: A TC String encoding user consent preferences constitutes personal data when it can be associated by reasonable means with identifiers allowing user identification.
semantic_quote: Article 4(1) of the GDPR states that personal data is 'any information relating to an identified or identifiable natural person', and specifies that 'an identifiable natural person is one who can be identified, directly or indirectly, in particular by reference to an identifier such as a name, an identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person'.
systematic_quote: It follows from Article 4(5) of the GDPR, read in conjunction with recital 26 of that regulation, that personal data which could be attributed to a natural person by the use of additional information must be considered to be information on an identifiable natural person.
teleological_quote: The use of the expression 'any information' in the definition of the concept of 'personal data' in that provision reflects the aim of the EU legislature to assign a wide scope to that concept, which potentially encompasses all kinds of information, not only objective but also subjective, in the form of opinions and assessments, provided that it 'relates to' the data subject.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope captures TC Strings even when organization lacks direct access to combined identifiers.

judges: C. Lycourgos;O. Spineanu-Matei;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: A sectoral organization establishing binding technical rules for consent management is a joint controller even without direct data access, but controllership does not automatically extend to subsequent third-party processing.
semantic_quote: Article 4(7) of the GDPR defines broadly the concept of 'controller' as referring to the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or any other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
systematic_quote: Since, as Article 4(7) of the GDPR expressly provides, the concept of 'controller' relates to the entity which 'alone or jointly with others' determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data, that concept does not necessarily refer to a single entity and may concern several actors taking part in that processing, with each of them then being subject to the applicable data protection provisions.
teleological_quote: The objective pursued by the GDPR, as is set out in Article 1 thereof and in recitals 1 and 10 thereof, consists, inter alia, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data, as enshrined in Article 8(1) of the Charter and Article 16(1) TFEU.
direction_justification: Broad joint controller interpretation extends accountability but limits do not automatically extend to subsequent processing, balancing controller burden.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb
core_holding: Valid consent requires active behaviour by the data subject with prior clear information, and cannot be established through pre-ticked boxes, misleading contract terms, or requirements to formally refuse consent.
semantic_quote: Article 2(h) of that directive defines the term 'consent' as meaning 'any freely given specific and informed indication of his wishes by which the data subject signifies his agreement to personal data relating to him being processed'.
systematic_quote: It is also apparent from the second indent of Article 10(c) of Directive 95/46 and from Article 13(2)(b) and (c) of Regulation 2016/679, read in the light of recital 42 of that regulation, that, in order to ensure that the data subject enjoys genuine freedom of choice, the contractual terms must not mislead him or her as to the possibility of concluding the contract even if he or she refuses to consent to the processing of his or her data.
teleological_quote: To the extent that those provisions set out that the data subject is to give an 'indication of his wishes' in order to give 'unambiguously' his consent, only active behaviour by that person with a view to giving his or her consent may be relevant.
direction_justification: The Court imposes strict requirements on controllers for demonstrating valid consent, rejecting pre-ticked boxes and requiring active behaviour from data subjects.

judges: O. Spineanu-Matei;J.-C. Bonichot;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: Commercial interests can constitute legitimate interests under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR, but processing must be strictly necessary and fundamental rights must not override the legitimate interest.
semantic_quote: While the concept of 'legitimate interest', within the meaning of point (f) of the first subparagraph of Article 6(1) of the GDPR, is not limited to interests enshrined in and determined by law, it requires that the alleged legitimate interest be lawful.
systematic_quote: In that context, it should also be recalled that the condition relating to the need for processing must be examined in conjunction with the 'data minimisation' principle enshrined in Article 5(1)(c) of the GDPR, in accordance with which personal data must be 'adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed'.
teleological_quote: In order to answer those questions, it should, as a preliminary point, be borne in mind that the objective pursued by the GDPR, as is set out in Article 1 thereof and in recitals 1 and 10 thereof, consists, inter alia, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data, as enshrined in Article 8(1) of the Charter and Article 16(1) TFEU.
direction_justification: The Court emphasizes strict necessity, data minimization, and reasonable expectations of data subjects, suggesting that selling member data without consent is unlikely to satisfy Article 6(1)(f) requirements.
other_rights: freedom to conduct a business

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Credit scoring by a credit information agency constitutes automated individual decision-making under Article 22(1) GDPR when a third party relies strongly on that score for contractual decisions.
semantic_quote: The applicability of that provision is therefore subject to three cumulative conditions, namely, first, that there must be a 'decision', secondly, that that decision must be 'based solely on automated processing, including profiling', and, thirdly, that it must produce 'legal effects concerning [the interested party]' or 'similarly significantly [affect] him or her'.
systematic_quote: The concept of 'decision' within the meaning of Article 22(1) of the GDPR is thus, as the Advocate General noted in point 38 of his Opinion, capable of including a number of acts which may affect the data subject in many ways, since that concept is broad enough to encompass the result of calculating a person's creditworthiness in the form of a probability value concerning that person's ability to meet payment commitments in the future.
teleological_quote: Those enhanced requirements as to the lawfulness of automated decision-making and the additional information obligations of the controller and the related additional rights of access of the data subject are explained by the purpose pursued by Article 22 of the GDPR, consisting of protecting individuals against the particular risks to their rights and freedoms represented by the automated processing of personal data, including profiling.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of automated decision-making extends Article 22 protections to credit scoring, expanding data subject rights and controller obligations.

judges: N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec;N. Piçarra
core_holding: National law may designate an auxiliary administrative entity without legal personality as controller if it can fulfil controller obligations and the law determines the scope of processing.
semantic_quote: As a preliminary point, it must be recalled that, under Article 4(7) of the GDPR, the concept of 'controller' covers natural or legal persons, public authorities, agencies or other bodies which, alone or jointly with others, determine the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
systematic_quote: That provision also states that, where the purposes and means of such processing are determined, inter alia, by the law of a Member State, the controller may be nominated or the specific criteria for its nomination may be provided for by that law.
teleological_quote: It is apparent from the case-law of the Court that that provision is intended to ensure, through a broad definition of the concept of 'controller', effective and complete protection of data subjects.
direction_justification: Allows entities without legal personality to be controllers (pro-controller flexibility) but requires them to fulfill all controller obligations toward data subjects (pro-data subject protection).

judges: K. Lenaerts;R. Silva de Lapuerta;A. Arabadjiev;A. Prechal;M. Vilaras;M. Ilešič;N. Wahl;E. Juhász;D. Šváby;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;P.G. Xuereb;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: A non-lead supervisory authority may initiate legal proceedings regarding cross-border processing only in specific situations where GDPR confers decision-making competence on it.
semantic_quote: Article 55(1) of Regulation 2016/679 states the general rule that each supervisory authority is to be competent for the performance of the tasks assigned to it and the exercise of the powers conferred on it, in accordance with that regulation, on the territory of its own Member State.
systematic_quote: It follows more specifically from Articles 56 and 60 of Regulation 2016/679 that, with respect to 'cross-border processing', within the meaning of Article 4, point (23), of that regulation, and subject to Article 56(2) thereof, the various national supervisory authorities concerned must cooperate, in accordance with the procedure laid down in those provisions, in order to reach a consensus and a single decision, which is binding on all those authorities.
teleological_quote: Regulation 2016/679 requires the European Union institutions, bodies, offices and agencies, and the competent authorities of the Member States, to ensure a high level of protection of the rights guaranteed in Article 16 TFEU and Article 8 of the Charter.
direction_justification: Allows non-lead DPA to bring proceedings in limited circumstances but confirms one-stop-shop constraints on enforcement powers.

judges: K. Lenaerts;R. Silva de Lapuerta;A. Arabadjiev;A. Prechal;M. Vilaras;M. Ilešič;N. Wahl;E. Juhász;D. Šváby;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;P.G. Xuereb;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: A non-lead supervisory authority may bring legal proceedings without requiring the controller to have an establishment in that authority's Member State.
semantic_quote: Article 58(5) of Regulation 2016/679 is worded in general terms and that the EU legislature has not specified that the exercise of that power by a Member State's supervisory authority is subject to the condition that its legal action should be brought against a controller who has a 'main establishment'.
systematic_quote: Article 3(1) of Regulation 2016/679, which governs the territorial scope of that regulation, provides, in that regard, that the regulation applies to the processing of personal data in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the European Union, whether or not the processing takes place in the European Union.
direction_justification: Expands DPA enforcement capacity by removing establishment requirement as precondition for legal action in cross-border cases.

judges: K. Lenaerts;R. Silva de Lapuerta;A. Arabadjiev;A. Prechal;M. Vilaras;M. Ilešič;N. Wahl;E. Juhász;D. Šváby;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;P.G. Xuereb;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: A non-lead supervisory authority may bring proceedings against any establishment of a controller if processing occurs in context of that establishment's activities.
semantic_quote: That provision does not restrict the exercise of the power to initiate or engage in legal proceedings in such a way that those proceedings can solely be brought against a 'main establishment' or against some other 'establishment' of the controller.
systematic_quote: Article 3(1) of that regulation provides that it is applicable to the processing of personal data 'in the context of the activities of an establishment of a controller or a processor in the Union, regardless of whether the processing takes place in the Union or not'.
teleological_quote: Having regard to the objective pursued by Regulation 2016/679, which is to ensure effective protection of the freedoms and fundamental rights of individuals, in particular, their right to protection of privacy and the protection of personal data, the condition that the processing of personal data must be carried out 'in the context of the activities' of the establishment concerned, cannot be interpreted restrictively.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of establishment activities allows DPA enforcement against local establishments even when main establishment is elsewhere.

judges: K. Lenaerts;R. Silva de Lapuerta;A. Arabadjiev;A. Prechal;M. Vilaras;M. Ilešič;N. Wahl;E. Juhász;D. Šváby;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;P.G. Xuereb;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: Legal proceedings commenced before GDPR application may continue under prior Directive for pre-existing infringements and under GDPR for subsequent ones.
semantic_quote: Regulation 2016/679 contains no transitional rule nor any other rule governing the status of court proceedings which were initiated before that regulation became applicable and which were still ongoing when it became applicable.
systematic_quote: In particular, there is no provision of that regulation which states that its effect is to bring to an end all court proceedings that are pending as at 25 May 2018 concerning alleged infringements of rules governing the processing of personal data laid down by Directive 95/46, even where the conduct that is a constituent element of such alleged infringements persists beyond that date.
direction_justification: Preserves DPA ability to continue enforcement proceedings spanning transition from Directive to GDPR without dismissal.

judges: K. Lenaerts;R. Silva de Lapuerta;A. Arabadjiev;A. Prechal;M. Vilaras;M. Ilešič;N. Wahl;E. Juhász;D. Šváby;S. Rodin;F. Biltgen;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;P.G. Xuereb;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: Article 58(5) has direct effect, allowing supervisory authorities to rely on it for legal proceedings even without national implementation.
semantic_quote: Article 58(5) of Regulation 2016/679 states that each Member State is to provide by law that its supervisory authority is to have the power to bring infringements of this Regulation to the attention of the judicial authorities and where appropriate, to initiate or engage otherwise in legal proceedings, in order to enforce the provisions of that regulation.
systematic_quote: Under the second paragraph of Article 288 TFEU, a regulation is to be binding in its entirety and is to be directly applicable in all Member States, so that its provisions do not, as a general rule, require the adoption of any implementing measures by the Member States.
direction_justification: Strengthens DPA enforcement capacity by ensuring legal standing exists directly from GDPR regardless of national transposition.

judges: N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec;I. Ziemele
core_holding: National rules adopted under Article 88(1) GDPR for employment data processing must also comply with the requirements of Articles 5, 6(1), and 9(1) and (2) GDPR.
semantic_quote: However, that wording does not provide any express indication as to whether the 'more specific rules' that the Member States thus have the possibility of adopting must seek to ensure compliance only with the requirements laid down in Article 88(2) of the GDPR or also with those of other provisions of that regulation, so that the processing of personal data carried out pursuant to such rules should also comply with those latter provisions.
systematic_quote: Article 88 of the GDPR appears in Chapter IX thereof, entitled 'Provisions relating to specific processing situations', while Articles 5, 6 and 9 of that regulation appear in Chapter II thereof, entitled 'Principles', which is therefore more general in scope.
teleological_quote: However, in order not to undermine all of those objectives, and in particular that of ensuring a high level of protection for employees where their personal data are processed in the employment context, Article 88 of the GDPR cannot be interpreted as meaning that the 'more specific rules' which the Member States have the option of adopting pursuant to that article could have the purpose or effect of circumventing the obligations of the controller or processor resulting from other provisions of that regulation.
direction_justification: Limits Member State discretion by requiring full compliance with core GDPR data protection principles even when adopting specific employment rules.

judges: N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec;I. Ziemele
core_holding: National courts must conduct full judicial review of collective agreements to verify necessity of data processing, notwithstanding the parties' margin of discretion.
semantic_quote: By its second question, the referring court asks, in essence, whether Article 88(1) of the GDPR must be interpreted as meaning that, where a collective agreement falls within the scope of that provision, the margin of discretion that the parties to that agreement have to determine whether the processing of personal data is 'necessary', within the meaning of Article 5, Article 6(1) and Article 9(1) and (2) of that regulation, has the effect of preventing the national court from carrying out a full judicial review in that regard.
teleological_quote: However, such an assessment process must not lead to those parties reaching compromises, on the basis of economic or practical considerations, which would be liable improperly to undermine the GDPR's objective of ensuring a high level of protection of employees' freedoms and fundamental rights with regard to the processing of their personal data.
direction_justification: Ensures employees can challenge collective agreements that inadequately protect their data rights through full judicial review.

judges: I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;A. Arabadjiev;M. Condinanzi;R. Frendo
core_holding: The GDPR does not provide a judicial remedy for data subjects to obtain preventive injunctions against future unlawful processing, but Member States may establish such remedies under national law.
semantic_quote: It should be noted that the GDPR contains no provisions which provide, explicitly or implicitly, that the data subject enjoys, as envisaged by the referring court, a right to obtain, as a preventive measure and by means of judicial proceedings, an order that the controller of personal data refrain, in future, from committing an infringement of the provisions of that regulation.
systematic_quote: As a preliminary point, it must be borne in mind that, in interpreting a provision of EU law, it is necessary to consider not only its wording but also its context and the objectives pursued by the legislation of which it forms part.
teleological_quote: The possibility for the data subject to bring a legal action seeking an order requiring a controller to refrain, in future, from infringing the substantive provisions of the GDPR does not undermine those objectives but is, in fact, such as to enhance the effectiveness of those provisions and thus the high level of protection of data subjects with regard to the processing of their personal data, pursued by that regulation.
direction_justification: While not creating a new EU-level remedy, the ruling preserves Member State discretion to provide preventive remedies, neither expanding nor restricting existing rights.

judges: I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;A. Arabadjiev;M. Condinanzi;R. Frendo
core_holding: Non-material damage under Article 82(1) includes negative feelings such as fear or annoyance caused by loss of control over personal data, potential misuse, or reputational harm from unauthorized data transmission.
semantic_quote: It should be observed that Article 82(1) of the GDPR provides that any person who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of that regulation is entitled to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered.
systematic_quote: In accordance with settled case-law, having regard to the absence of any reference in Article 82(1) of the GDPR to the domestic law of the Member States, the concept of 'non-material damage', within the meaning of that provision, must be given an autonomous and uniform definition specific to EU law.
teleological_quote: In addition, it is supported by the objective of that regulation, as set out in Article 1 and recitals 1 and 10 thereof, which is to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of non-material damage to include negative feelings without requiring a severity threshold expands data subjects' ability to claim compensation.

judges: I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;A. Arabadjiev;M. Condinanzi;R. Frendo
core_holding: The degree of fault on the part of the controller cannot be taken into account when assessing the amount of compensation for non-material damage under Article 82(1) GDPR.
semantic_quote: It is apparent from the case-law of the Court that, since the GDPR does not contain any provision intended to define the rules on the assessment of damages payable under the right to compensation enshrined in Article 82 of that regulation, national courts must, to that end, apply the domestic rules of each Member State.
systematic_quote: In contrast to what is provided for in Article 83 of the GDPR for administrative fines, the criteria for which are not applicable mutatis mutandis in the context of Article 82 of that regulation, the right to compensation provided for in Article 82, in particular in the case of non-material damage, fulfils an exclusively compensatory function.
teleological_quote: The Court has held that, in view of the compensatory function of the right to compensation under Article 82 of the GDPR, national courts are required to ensure 'full and effective' compensation for the damage suffered.
direction_justification: Excluding degree of fault from damage assessment limits the amount controllers may have to pay, preventing punitive or enhanced damages based on culpability.

judges: I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;A. Arabadjiev;M. Condinanzi;R. Frendo
core_holding: Obtaining a prohibitory injunction under national law cannot reduce or replace the financial compensation for non-material damage payable under Article 82(1) GDPR.
semantic_quote: It is apparent from the case-law referred to in paragraphs 78 and 79 above that a form of compensation provided for by the applicable national law may be regarded as compatible with the GDPR only in so far as that form of compensation is in line with the principles of equivalence and effectiveness of EU law.
systematic_quote: In particular, compensation payable under Article 82 of that regulation cannot be awarded, in part or in full, in the form of a prohibitory injunction, since the right to compensation for damage provided for in Article 82 fulfils an exclusively compensatory function.
teleological_quote: In particular, it should be noted that the criteria for assessing the compensation payable in the context of actions intended to safeguard the rights which individuals derive from Article 82 of the GDPR, criteria which are prescribed within the legal system of each Member State, must ensure that the compensation for the damage suffered by the data subject as a result of an infringement of that regulation is full and effective.
direction_justification: Preventing reduction or substitution of financial compensation ensures data subjects receive full monetary redress regardless of other remedies obtained.

judges: M. Safjan;N. Piçarra;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Verification of COVID-19 certificates using a mobile application constitutes processing of personal data within the meaning of Article 4(2) GDPR.
semantic_quote: It is apparent from the wording of that provision, and in particular from the expression 'any operation', that the EU legislature intended the concept of 'processing' to have a broad meaning.
systematic_quote: The interpretation referred to in paragraph 30 of the present judgment is corroborated by Regulation 2021/953, which provides that the implementation of the EU Digital COVID Certificate constitutes processing within the meaning of Article 4(2) of the GDPR.
teleological_quote: That broad interpretation of 'personal data' and 'processing' is consistent with the objective of guaranteeing the effectiveness of the fundamental right of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data, referred to in recital 1 of the GDPR, which sets the tone for the application of that regulation.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of processing captures mobile app verification activities that might otherwise escape GDPR regulation.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: The Article 9(2)(h) exception applies when a medical service processes health data of its own employee to assess working capacity, provided it acts as medical service not employer.
semantic_quote: Article 9(2)(h) of the GDPR authorises such processing if it is 'necessary for the purposes of [inter alia] the assessment of the working capacity of the employee … on the basis of Union or Member State law or pursuant to contract with a health professional'.
systematic_quote: It follows from Article 9(2)(h) of the GDPR, read in conjunction with Article 9(3), that the possibility of processing sensitive data, such as data concerning health, is strictly regulated by a series of cumulative conditions.
teleological_quote: Thus, recital 4 of the GDPR states that the right to the protection of personal data is not an absolute right, since it must be considered in relation to its function in society and be balanced against other fundamental rights, in accordance with the principle of proportionality.
direction_justification: Allows medical service to process health data of its own employees, recognizing dual function and rejecting requirement for neutral third party.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Article 9(3) does not require controllers to prevent all colleagues from accessing employee health data, though Member State law or security principles may impose such obligations.
semantic_quote: Personal data referred to in paragraph 1 may be processed for the purposes referred to in point (h) of paragraph 2 when those data are processed by or under the responsibility of a professional subject to the obligation of professional secrecy under Union or Member State law.
systematic_quote: By adopting Article 9(3) of that regulation, which refers specifically to Article 9(2)(h) of that article, the EU legislature defined the specific protection measures it intended to impose on controllers of such processing, which consist in such processing being reserved to persons subject to an obligation of secrecy.
direction_justification: Does not require absolute colleague exclusion under Article 9(3), but recognizes Member States may impose such requirements and security principles apply.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Processing health data under Article 9(2)(h) must also satisfy at least one lawfulness condition under Article 6(1) in addition to Article 9 requirements.
semantic_quote: In addition, it should be noted that recital 51 of the GDPR expressly states that, 'in addition to the specific requirements' for the processing of 'particularly sensitive' data, which are set out in Article 9(2) and (3) of that regulation, 'the general principles and other rules of [that] Regulation should [also] apply [to such processing], in particular as regards the conditions for lawful processing'.
systematic_quote: It should be recalled that Articles 5, 6 and 9 of the GDPR are in Chapter II of that regulation, entitled 'Principles', and concern principles relating to processing of personal data, conditions for the lawfulness of processing and processing of special categories of personal data, respectively.
direction_justification: Requires cumulative compliance with both Article 9 and Article 6(1), increasing controller obligations for health data processing.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82(1) fulfils a compensatory function only, not a dissuasive or punitive function.
semantic_quote: Article 82(1) of the GDPR states that 'any person who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of this Regulation shall have the right to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered'.
systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
teleological_quote: In that regard, first, it is apparent from the wording of Articles 24 and 32 of the GDPR that those provisions merely require the controller to adopt technical and organisational measures intended to avoid, in so far as it is at all possible, any personal data breach.
direction_justification: Rejects punitive damages function, limiting compensation to actual damage suffered and excluding consideration of infringement gravity.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Controller liability under Article 82 requires fault, which is presumed but rebuttable; fault severity does not affect damages amount.
semantic_quote: Article 82(3) of the GDPR specifies, from that perspective, that a controller is exempt from liability under Article 82(2) of that regulation if it proves that it is not in any way responsible for the event giving rise to the damage.
systematic_quote: It therefore follows from a combined analysis of those various provisions of Article 82 of the GDPR that that article provides for fault-based liability in which the burden of proof rests not on the person who has suffered damage, but on the controller.
teleological_quote: With regard to the objectives of the GDPR, it is clear from recitals 4 to 8 of that regulation that it seeks to strike a balance between the interests of controllers of personal data and the rights of data subjects whose personal data are processed.
direction_justification: Presumed fault benefits data subjects by reversing burden of proof, but excluding fault severity from damages calculation benefits controllers.

judges: K. Lenaerts;R. Silva de Lapuerta;J.-C. Bonichot;M. Vilaras;T. von Danwitz;C. Toader;F. Biltgen;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;A. Rosas;L. Bay Larsen;M. Safjan;S. Rodin
core_holding: Consent for cookie storage is not valid when obtained through a pre-checked checkbox that users must deselect to refuse consent.
provisions_cited: Article 2(f) Directive 2002/58;Article 5(3) Directive 2002/58;Article 2(h) Directive 95/46;Article 4(11) GDPR;Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
semantic_quote: The wording 'given his or her consent' does, however, lend itself to a literal interpretation according to which action is required on the part of the user in order to give his or her consent.
systematic_quote: Article 2(f) of that directive, which defines 'consent', for the purposes thereof, refers, in that regard, to the 'data subject's consent' set out in Directive 95/46.
teleological_quote: Lastly, as regards the origins of Article 5(3) of Directive 2002/58, the initial wording of that provision provided only for the requirement that the user had the 'right to refuse' the storage of cookies, after having received, pursuant to Directive 95/46, clear and comprehensive information, inter alia, regarding the purpose of the data processing.
direction_justification: Strict interpretation of consent requiring active affirmative action protects users against unwanted cookie tracking via default pre-checked boxes.

judges: K. Lenaerts;R. Silva de Lapuerta;J.-C. Bonichot;M. Vilaras;T. von Danwitz;C. Toader;F. Biltgen;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;A. Rosas;L. Bay Larsen;M. Safjan;S. Rodin
core_holding: The consent requirement for cookie storage applies regardless of whether the stored information constitutes personal data.
provisions_cited: Article 2(f) Directive 2002/58;Article 5(3) Directive 2002/58;Article 2(h) Directive 95/46;Article 4(11) GDPR;Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
semantic_quote: Article 5(3) of Directive 2002/58 refers to 'the storing of information' and 'the gaining of access to information already stored', without characterising that information or specifying that it must be personal data.
systematic_quote: That protection applies to any information stored in such terminal equipment, regardless of whether or not it is personal data, and is intended, in particular, as is clear from that recital, to protect users from the risk that hidden identifiers and other similar devices enter those users' terminal equipment without their knowledge.
teleological_quote: As the Advocate General stated in point 107 of his Opinion, that provision aims to protect the user from interference with his or her private sphere, regardless of whether or not that interference involves personal data.
direction_justification: Extends protection to all information stored on user terminal equipment, not just personal data, broadening scope of user privacy protection.

judges: K. Lenaerts;R. Silva de Lapuerta;J.-C. Bonichot;M. Vilaras;T. von Danwitz;C. Toader;F. Biltgen;K. Jürimäe;C. Lycourgos;A. Rosas;L. Bay Larsen;M. Safjan;S. Rodin
core_holding: Service providers must inform users about cookie duration and whether third parties may access the cookies.
semantic_quote: Clear and comprehensive information implies that a user is in a position to be able to determine easily the consequences of any consent he or she might give and ensure that the consent given is well informed.
systematic_quote: That information includes, inter alia, under Article 10 of Directive 95/46, in addition to the identity of the controller and the purposes of the processing for which the data are intended, any further information such as the recipients or categories of recipients of the data in so far as such further information is necessary, having regard to the specific circumstances in which the data are processed, to guarantee fair processing in respect of the data subject.
teleological_quote: Information on the duration of the operation of cookies must be regarded as meeting the requirement of fair data processing provided for in that article in that, in a situation such as that at issue in the main proceedings, a long, or even unlimited, duration means collecting a large amount of information on users' surfing behaviour and how often they may visit the websites of the organiser of the promotional lottery's advertising partners.
direction_justification: Expands transparency obligations by requiring disclosure of cookie duration and third-party access, enhancing user information rights.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Arabadjiev;C. Lycourgos;E. Regan;T. von Danwitz;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei;M. Ilešič;J.-C. Bonichot;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Jääskinen;N. Wahl;M. Gavalec
core_holding: An entity commissioning a mobile app may be a controller if it participated in determining processing purposes and means, even without performing processing operations itself.
semantic_quote: Article 4(7) of the GDPR defines the concept of 'controller' broadly as the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or any other body which, alone or jointly with others, 'determines the purposes and means of the processing' of personal data.
systematic_quote: It is apparent from that provision, read in the light of recital 74 of the GDPR, that an entity, provided that it satisfies the condition laid down by Article 4(7) of that regulation, is responsible and liable not only for any processing of personal data which it itself carries out, but also for any such processing carried out on its behalf.
teleological_quote: The objective of that broad definition consists, in accordance with the objective pursued by the GDPR, in ensuring effective protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and, in particular, in ensuring a high level of protection of the right of every person to the protection of personal data concerning him or her.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of controller captures entities that commission apps but do not themselves process data, expanding accountability.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Arabadjiev;C. Lycourgos;E. Regan;T. von Danwitz;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei;M. Ilešič;J.-C. Bonichot;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Jääskinen;N. Wahl;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Joint controller classification does not require a formal arrangement between entities regarding purposes, means, or terms of joint control.
semantic_quote: Under Article 26(1) of the GDPR, 'joint controllers' exist where two or more controllers jointly determine the purposes and means of processing.
systematic_quote: However, the existence of such an arrangement constitutes not a precondition for two or more entities to be classified as joint controllers, but rather an obligation which Article 26(1) of the GDPR imposes on joint controllers, once they have been classified as such, for the purposes of compliance with their obligations under that regulation.
direction_justification: Broadens joint controller status by not requiring formal arrangements, making it easier to hold multiple parties accountable.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Arabadjiev;C. Lycourgos;E. Regan;T. von Danwitz;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei;M. Ilešič;J.-C. Bonichot;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Jääskinen;N. Wahl;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Using personal data for IT testing constitutes processing unless the data are anonymous, anonymized, or fictitious relating to non-existent persons.
semantic_quote: It is therefore apparent from the wording of that provision, and in particular from the expression 'any operation', that the EU legislature intended to confer a broad scope upon the concept of 'processing'.
systematic_quote: It follows from recital 26 of the GDPR and from the very definition of the concept of 'personal data' provided in Article 4(1) of that regulation that neither 'anonymous information, namely information which does not relate to an identified or identifiable natural person', nor 'personal data rendered anonymous in such a manner that the data subject is not or no longer identifiable', is covered by that concept.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of processing covers IT testing purposes, expanding GDPR applicability to development activities.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Arabadjiev;C. Lycourgos;E. Regan;T. von Danwitz;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei;M. Ilešič;J.-C. Bonichot;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Jääskinen;N. Wahl;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Administrative fines require intentional or negligent infringement; controllers may be fined for processor operations unless processor acted outside the agreed framework.
semantic_quote: As regards, in the first place, the question whether an administrative fine may be imposed pursuant to Article 83 of the GDPR only in so far as it is established that the controller or processor has intentionally or negligently committed an infringement referred to in paragraphs 4 to 6 of that article, it is apparent from paragraph 1 thereof that such fines must be effective, proportionate and dissuasive.
systematic_quote: It thus follows from such a combined reading of those provisions that the determination of substantive conditions for imposing such administrative fines falls outside the scope of that power.
teleological_quote: Through their dissuasive effect, administrative fines contribute to strengthening the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and are therefore a key element in ensuring respect for the rights of those persons, in accordance with the purpose of that regulation, which is to ensure a high level of protection for such persons with regard to the processing of personal data.
direction_justification: Requires fault for fines (pro-controller) but allows controller liability for processor actions within agreed scope (pro-data subject).

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Employee error in providing documents containing personal data to an unauthorized third party is not sufficient in itself to conclude that the controller's technical and organizational measures were inappropriate.
semantic_quote: It is apparent, accordingly, from the wording of Articles 24 and 32 of the GDPR that the appropriateness of the measures implemented by the controller must be assessed in a concrete manner, taking into account the various criteria referred to in those articles and the data protection needs specifically inherent in the processing concerned and the risks arising from the latter.
systematic_quote: That literal interpretation is supported by reading Articles 24 and 32 together with Article 5(2) and Article 82 of that regulation, read in the light of recitals 74, 76 and 83 thereof, from which it follows, in particular, that the controller is obliged to mitigate the risks of personal data breaches and not prevent all breaches of those data.
teleological_quote: Such an allocation of the burden of proof is capable not only of encouraging the controllers of those data of adopting the security measures required by the GDPR, but also in retaining the effectiveness of the right to compensation provided for in Article 82 of that regulation and upholding the intentions of the EU legislature referred to in recital 11 thereof.
direction_justification: Holding prevents automatic finding of inadequate security measures based solely on occurrence of a breach, requiring concrete assessment that benefits controllers.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: The right to compensation under Article 82 fulfills a compensatory function requiring full compensation for damage suffered, not a punitive function.
systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
teleological_quote: The right of any person to seek compensation for damage reinforces the operational nature of the protection rules laid down by that regulation and is likely to discourage the reoccurrence of unlawful conduct.
direction_justification: Clarifies the nature of compensation without expanding or limiting rights in a way that favors either party.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: Article 82 does not require that the severity of the controller's infringement be taken into consideration when determining compensation amounts.
semantic_quote: It follows from Article 82 of the GDPR that, first, establishing the liability of the controller is, in particular, subject to fault on the part of the controller, which is presupposed unless it proves that it is not in any way responsible for the event giving rise to the damage, and secondly, Article 82 does not require that the severity of that fault is taken into consideration when setting the amount of the compensation allocated for non-material damage under that provision.
teleological_quote: Having regard to the compensatory function of the right to compensation laid down in Article 82 of the GDPR, that provision does not require taking into consideration the severity of the infringement of that regulation, that the controller is presumed to have made, while setting the amount of the compensation allocated for non-material damage under that provision, but requires that that amount is set in a way that the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation is compensated in full.
direction_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage without allowing increases based on severity of infringement, benefiting controllers facing minor but technically serious violations.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: A person seeking compensation must establish both an infringement of the GDPR and that the infringement caused material or non-material damage.
semantic_quote: It is apparent from the wording of that provision that the mere infringement of the GDPR is not sufficient to confer a right to compensation.
teleological_quote: The Court stated that a person concerned by an infringement of the GDPR which had negative consequences for him or her is, however, required to demonstrate that those consequences constitute non-material damage, within the meaning of Article 82 of that regulation, since the mere infringement of the provisions thereof are not sufficient to confer a right to compensation.
direction_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, creating an additional burden that benefits controllers.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;M. Safjan;N. Jääskinen;M. Gavalec
core_holding: When an unauthorized third party did not become aware of personal data, mere fear of future misuse does not constitute non-material damage sufficient for compensation.
semantic_quote: Having regard to the absence of any reference in Article 82(1) of the GDPR to the domestic law of the Member States, the concept of 'non-material damage', within the meaning of that provision, must be given an autonomous and uniform definition specific to EU law.
teleological_quote: The Court held that it is apparent not only from the wording of Article 82(1) of the GDPR, read in the light of recitals 85 and 146 of that regulation, which encourage the acceptance of a broad interpretation of the concept of 'non-material damage' within the meaning of that first provision, but also the objective of ensuring a high level of protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data, which is referred to by the regulation, that the fear experienced by a data subject with regard to a possible misuse of his or her personal data by third parties as a result of an infringement of that regulation is capable, in itself, of constituting 'non-material damage'.
direction_justification: Excludes compensation for hypothetical fear when unauthorized party did not actually access the data, limiting recoverable non-material damage.

judges: F. Biltgen;T. von Danwitz;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele;S. Gervasoni
core_holding: Data identifying a natural person representing a legal person (name, surname, signature, contact details) constitutes personal data, and its disclosure is processing regardless of purpose.
semantic_quote: According to settled case-law, the use of the expression 'any information' in the definition of the concept of 'personal data' in that provision reflects the aim of the EU legislature to assign a wide scope to that concept, which potentially encompasses all kinds of information, not only objective but also subjective, in the form of opinions and assessments, provided that it 'relates' to the data subject.
systematic_quote: As the Commission observed, that interpretation cannot be invalidated by recital 14 of the GDPR.
teleological_quote: That interpretation is consistent with the objective pursued by the GDPR, as is set out in Article 1 thereof and in recitals 1 and 10 thereof, consisting, inter alia, in ensuring a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data, as enshrined in Article 8(1) of the Charter and Article 16(1) TFEU.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of personal data scope includes representatives of legal persons, expanding GDPR protection.

judges: F. Biltgen;T. von Danwitz;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele;S. Gervasoni
core_holding: National case-law requiring prior consultation of data subjects before disclosure of official documents is permissible provided it does not impose disproportionate restrictions on public access.
semantic_quote: Article 6(3) of the GDPR provides that the basis for the processing referred to in Article 6(1)(c) and (e) is to be defined, as the case may be, by EU or Member State law to which the controller is subject.
systematic_quote: That article must be read in the light, first, of recital 4 of the GDPR, which states, inter alia, that the right to the protection of personal data is not an absolute right, second, of recital 154 of that regulation, from which it is apparent, inter alia, that public access to official documents may be considered to be in the public interest.
teleological_quote: Such an obligation is such as to ensure lawful, fair and transparent processing in respect of that data subject, within the meaning of Article 5(1)(a) of the GDPR, by allowing him or her to express his or her views on the proposed disclosure.
direction_justification: Permits national data subject protections but limits them through proportionality to protect public access rights.
other_rights: public access to official documents;transparency

judges: T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Oral disclosure of information on criminal proceedings concerning a natural person constitutes processing of personal data falling within the GDPR's material scope when the data form part of a filing system.
semantic_quote: Article 4(2) of the GDPR defines the concept of 'processing' as 'any operation or set of operations which is performed on personal data or on sets of personal data, whether or not by automated means'.
systematic_quote: Article 2 of that regulation, which determines that scope, provides, in paragraph 1, that that regulation applies to the processing 'wholly or partly by automated means' and to the processing 'other than by automated means of personal data which form part of a filing system or are intended to form part of a filing system'.
teleological_quote: That interpretation of the concept of 'processing' is supported by the objective pursued by the GDPR, which seeks, inter alia, as is apparent from Article 1 thereof and recitals 1 and 10 thereof, to ensure a high level of protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular their right to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data, as enshrined in Article 8(1) of the Charter and Article 16(1) TFEU.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of processing to include oral disclosure expands GDPR scope and prevents circumvention of data protection rules.

judges: T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;I. Ziemele
core_holding: Criminal conviction data in court filing systems cannot be disclosed orally to any person for public access purposes without the requester establishing a specific interest in obtaining the data.
semantic_quote: Under that provision, processing of those data 'shall be carried out only under the control of official authority', unless it is 'authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards for the rights and freedoms of data subjects'.
systematic_quote: It is important to note that, in accordance with the settled case-law of the Court, any processing of personal data must, first, comply with the principles relating to the processing of data established in Article 5 of the GDPR and, secondly, in the light, in particular, of the principle of the lawfulness of processing, laid down in Article 5(1)(a), satisfy one of the conditions of the lawfulness of the processing listed in Article 6 of that regulation.
teleological_quote: In the light in particular of the sensitivity of data relating to criminal convictions and of the seriousness of the interference with the fundamental rights of data subjects to respect for private life and to the protection of personal data, which is caused by the disclosure of such data, it must be held that those rights prevail over the public's interest in having access to official documents.
direction_justification: Court requires specific interest to be established before disclosure, prioritizing data subject privacy over unrestricted public access to criminal records.
other_rights: public access to official documents;freedom of information

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen
core_holding: An infringement of GDPR provisions conferring rights on data subjects is not sufficient in itself to constitute non-material damage requiring compensation.
semantic_quote: Article 82(1) of the GDPR provides that any person 'who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of this Regulation shall have the right to receive compensation from the controller or processor for the damage suffered'.
systematic_quote: However, that provision merely confers a right to bring an action on a person who considers himself or herself to be a victim of a breach of the rights conferred on him or her by the GDPR, without exempting that person from his or her obligation under Article 82(1) of that regulation to prove that he or she has actually suffered material or non-material damage.
teleological_quote: In that regard, it should be noted that recital 85 of the GDPR expressly mentions 'loss of control' among the damage that may be caused by a personal data breach.
direction_justification: Requires data subjects to prove actual damage beyond mere GDPR infringement, raising the threshold for compensation claims.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen
core_holding: A controller cannot be exempted from liability merely by claiming that damage was caused by an employee's failure to follow instructions.
semantic_quote: Article 32(4) of the GDPR, relating to the security of processing of personal data, provides that the controller is to take steps to ensure that any natural person acting under the authority of the controller, who has access to such data, does not process them, except on instructions from the controller.
systematic_quote: An employee of the controller is indeed a natural person acting under the authority of that controller.
teleological_quote: If it were accepted that the controller may be exempted from liability merely by relying on the failure of a person acting under his or her authority, that would undermine the effectiveness of the right to compensation enshrined in Article 82(1) of the GDPR and would not be consistent with the objective of that regulation, which is to ensure a high level of protection for individuals with regard to the processing of their personal data.
direction_justification: Controllers remain liable for employee failures and cannot easily escape responsibility, strengthening data subject compensation rights.

judges: K. Jürimäe;N. Piçarra;N. Jääskinen
core_holding: Administrative fine criteria under Article 83 do not apply to compensation assessment, and multiple infringements do not increase damages beyond actual harm suffered.
semantic_quote: While Article 83 of that regulation determines the 'general conditions for imposing administrative fines', Article 82 of that regulation governs the 'right to compensation and liability'.
systematic_quote: The relationship between the rules set out in Article 82 and those set out in Articles 83 and 84 shows that there is a difference between those two categories of provisions, but also complementarity, in terms of encouraging compliance with the GDPR.
teleological_quote: Referring to the sixth sentence of recital 146 of the GDPR, according to which that instrument is intended to ensure 'full and effective compensation for the damage … suffered', the Court noted that, in view of the compensatory function of the right to compensation provided for in Article 82 of that regulation, monetary compensation based on that article must be regarded as 'full and effective' if it allows the damage actually suffered as a result of the infringement of that regulation to be compensated in its entirety.
direction_justification: Limits compensation to actual damage suffered without punitive elements, preventing inflation of damages through multiple infringement counts.

judges: C. Lycourgos;O. Spineanu-Matei;J.-C. Bonichot;S. Rodin;L.S. Rossi
core_holding: Consumer protection associations may bring representative actions under Article 80(2) GDPR for violations of controller information obligations under Articles 12(1) and 13(1)(c) and (e).
semantic_quote: Specifically, as is apparent from the wording of Article 80(2) of the GDPR, the bringing of a representative action on the basis of that provision implies that the infringement of the rights which the data subject derives from that regulation occurs in the course of the processing of personal data.
systematic_quote: That interpretation is supported by a comparison of the different language versions of Article 80(2) of the GDPR and by recital 142 thereof, which states that entities meeting the conditions referred to in Article 80(1) of that regulation must have reasons to consider that the rights of a data subject under that regulation have been infringed as a result of 'the processing of personal data which infringes [that] Regulation'.
teleological_quote: That interpretation is confirmed, first, by the objective of the GDPR, recalled in paragraph 48 above, of ensuring effective protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and, in particular, a high level of protection of the right of every person to privacy with respect to the processing of personal data concerning him or her.
direction_justification: Broad interpretation of standing requirements allows consumer associations to bring actions for transparency violations, enhancing enforcement of data subject rights.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;T. von Danwitz;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: When a personal data breach is established, the supervisory authority is not required to exercise corrective powers where such action is not appropriate, necessary, or proportionate.
semantic_quote: Thus, under Article 58(2) of the GDPR, the supervisory authority has the power, inter alia, to issue reprimands to a controller or a processor where processing operations have infringed provisions of that regulation.
systematic_quote: In order to handle complaints thus lodged, Article 58(1) of the GDPR confers extensive investigative powers on each supervisory authority.
teleological_quote: That discretion is, however, limited by the need to ensure a consistent and high level of protection of personal data through strong enforcement of the rules, as is apparent from recitals 7 and 10 of the GDPR.
direction_justification: The ruling confirms that supervisory authorities have discretion not to impose fines or corrective measures even when a breach is established, reducing enforcement pressure on controllers.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;L. Bay Larsen;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: The purpose limitation principle does not preclude copying personal data to a test database for testing and error correction where such processing is compatible with the initial collection purposes.
semantic_quote: It is thus apparent from the wording of that provision that it comprises two requirements, one relating to the purposes of the initial collection of the personal data and the other concerning the further processing of those data.
systematic_quote: It follows from a combined reading of Article 5(1)(b), Article 6(1)(a) and Article 6(4) of Regulation 2016/679 that the question of the compatibility of the further processing of personal data with the purposes for which those data were initially collected arises only if the purposes of that further processing are not identical to the purposes of the initial collection.
teleological_quote: Furthermore, in the third place, as the Advocate General emphasised, in essence, in point 27 of his Opinion, those criteria limit the reuse of personal data previously collected by ensuring a balance between, on the one hand, the need for predictability and legal certainty regarding the purposes of the processing of personal data previously collected and, on the other hand, the recognition of a degree of flexibility for the controller in the management of those data, and thereby contribute to the attainment of the objective of ensuring a consistent and high level of protection of natural persons, which is set out in recital 10 of Regulation 2016/679.
direction_justification: The Court permits controllers flexibility to copy data to test databases for legitimate operational purposes without requiring separate consent or legal basis.

judges: A. Arabadjiev;L. Bay Larsen;P.G. Xuereb;A. Kumin;I. Ziemele
core_holding: The storage limitation principle precludes retaining personal data in a test database longer than necessary for conducting tests and correcting errors.
semantic_quote: It is thus unequivocally clear from the wording of that article that the principle of 'storage limitation' requires the controller to be able to demonstrate, in accordance with the principle of accountability referred to in paragraph 24 of the present judgment, that personal data are kept only for as long as is necessary for the purposes for which they were collected or for which they have been further processed.
systematic_quote: First, as is apparent from such Article 6, where the data subject has not given consent to the processing of his or her personal data for one or more specific purposes, in accordance with Article 6(1)(a) of Regulation 2016/679, the processing must, as is apparent from Article 6(1)(b) to (f), satisfy a requirement of necessity.
teleological_quote: Such an interpretation is, in the third place, consistent with the objective pursued by Article 5(1)(e) of Regulation 2016/679, which, as was recalled in paragraph 48 of the present judgment, is, inter alia, to ensure a high level of protection of natural persons within the European Union with regard to the processing of personal data.
direction_justification: The Court strictly enforces storage limitation, rejecting the controller's oversight argument and requiring deletion once the test purpose is fulfilled.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Arabadjiev;C. Lycourgos;E. Regan;T. von Danwitz;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei;M. Ilešič;J.-C. Bonichot;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Jääskinen;N. Wahl;M. Gavalec
core_holding: National law cannot require that a GDPR infringement be attributed to an identified natural person before imposing an administrative fine on a legal person controller.
semantic_quote: Article 4(7) of the GDPR defines the concept of 'controller' broadly, as referring to the natural or legal person, public authority, agency or other body which, alone or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of personal data.
systematic_quote: It thus follows from a combined reading of Article 4(7), Article 83 and Article 58(2)(i) of the GDPR that an administrative fine in respect of an infringement referred to in Article 83(4) to (6) may also be imposed on legal persons where they are controllers.
teleological_quote: The objective of that broad definition in Article 4(7) of the GDPR – which expressly includes legal persons – is, in a manner consistent with the objective of the GDPR, to ensure effective protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons and, in particular, to ensure a high level of protection of the right of every person to the protection of personal data concerning him or her.
direction_justification: Holding ensures effective enforcement by allowing direct fines on legal person controllers without requiring attribution to a natural person.

judges: K. Lenaerts;L. Bay Larsen;A. Arabadjiev;C. Lycourgos;E. Regan;T. von Danwitz;Z. Csehi;O. Spineanu-Matei;M. Ilešič;J.-C. Bonichot;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Jääskinen;N. Wahl;M. Gavalec
core_holding: An administrative fine under Article 83 GDPR may only be imposed where the controller intentionally or negligently committed the infringement.
semantic_quote: Accordingly, it follows from the wording of Article 83(2) of the GDPR that only infringements of the provisions of that regulation committed wrongfully by the controller, that is to say those committed intentionally or negligently, can result in a fine being imposed on the controller pursuant to that article.
systematic_quote: Article 83(2) of the GDPR must be read in conjunction with Article 83(3) thereof, the purpose of which is to lay down the consequences of cumulative infringements of that regulation, according to which 'if a controller or processor intentionally or negligently, for the same or linked processing operations, infringes several provisions of this Regulation, the total amount of the administrative fine shall not exceed the amount specified for the gravest infringement'.
teleological_quote: Through their deterrent effect, administrative fines contribute to strengthening the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and therefore constitute a key element in ensuring respect for the rights of those persons, in accordance with the purpose of that regulation of ensuring a high level of protection of such persons with regard to the processing of personal data.
direction_justification: Requires proof of intentional or negligent conduct before imposing administrative fines, rejecting strict liability.

judges: K. Lenaerts;A. Arabadjiev;S. Rodin;I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;T. von Danwitz;M. Safjan;F. Biltgen;P.G. Xuereb;N. Piçarra;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: The GDPR applies to PNR data processing by private operators and to API/maritime directive processing, but not to PNR Directive processing carried out by PIUs or competent authorities.
semantic_quote: Article 2(2)(d) of the GDPR draws such a distinction, since it is clearly apparent from the wording of that provision that two conditions need to be met for data processing to fall within the scope of the exception it lays down.
systematic_quote: As is apparent from recital 19 of the GDPR, the reason for that exception is that the processing of personal data by authorities competent for the purposes, inter alia, of the prevention and detection of criminal offences is governed by a more specific EU legal act, namely Directive 2016/680.
teleological_quote: Directive 2016/680 lays down the specific rules relating to the protection of natural persons with regard to such processing operations, respecting the specific nature of those activities in the fields of judicial cooperation in criminal matters and police cooperation.
direction_justification: The holding clarifies the boundary between GDPR and Directive 2016/680 without expanding or restricting rights.

judges: K. Lenaerts;A. Arabadjiev;S. Rodin;I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;T. von Danwitz;M. Safjan;F. Biltgen;P.G. Xuereb;N. Piçarra;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: The PNR Directive is valid when interpreted in light of Charter Articles 7, 8, 21 and 52(1), subject to strict interpretive safeguards limiting data scope, processing purposes, and automated assessment.
semantic_quote: PNR data collected and provided in accordance with Annex I to the PNR Directive must relate directly to the flight operated and the passenger concerned and must be limited in such a way as to meet solely the legitimate requirements of public authorities.
systematic_quote: That directive, in Article 1(2) thereof read in conjunction with Article 3(8) and (9) thereof as well as Annex II thereto, circumscribes the purposes for which those data are to be processed.
teleological_quote: The objectives of the directive are to ensure the internal security of the European Union and thus protect the life and safety of persons, while creating a legal framework that guarantees a high level of protection of passengers' fundamental rights.
direction_justification: Court imposes strict interpretive limits on PNR Directive requiring narrow construction of data categories, assessment criteria, and processing purposes to protect fundamental rights.
other_rights: public security;internal security

judges: K. Lenaerts;A. Arabadjiev;S. Rodin;I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;T. von Danwitz;M. Safjan;F. Biltgen;P.G. Xuereb;N. Piçarra;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: National legislation cannot authorize PNR data processing for purposes other than those expressly listed in Article 1(2) of the PNR Directive, such as intelligence service monitoring.
semantic_quote: Article 1(2) of the PNR Directive states expressly that the PNR data collected in accordance with that directive may be processed only for the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offences and serious crime.
systematic_quote: It is thus clear from the wording of those provisions that the list included therein of the objectives pursued by the processing of PNR data under the PNR Directive is exhaustive.
teleological_quote: That interpretation is supported by recital 11 of the PNR Directive, according to which the processing of PNR data should be proportionate to the specific security goals pursued by that directive.
direction_justification: Precludes expansion of PNR data use to intelligence services or purposes beyond the directive's explicit objectives, limiting data processing scope.

judges: K. Lenaerts;A. Arabadjiev;S. Rodin;I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;T. von Danwitz;M. Safjan;F. Biltgen;P.G. Xuereb;N. Piçarra;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: The PIU cannot also be designated as the competent authority to approve disclosure of PNR data after six months, as it lacks the required independence.
