semantic_quote: It follows from that wording that the other competent national authority thus referred to is an alternative to the judicial authority and, accordingly, must have a level of independence and impartiality similar to the latter.
systematic_quote: That analysis is supported by the objective of the PNR Directive, mentioned in recital 25 thereof, to ensure the highest level of data protection concerning access to the full PNR data.
teleological_quote: That same recital specifies that that access should be granted only under very strict conditions after the period of six months following the transfer of PNR data to the PIU.
direction_justification: Strengthens procedural safeguards by requiring independent approval for data disclosure, preventing PIU from being both data processor and disclosure approver.

judges: K. Lenaerts;A. Arabadjiev;S. Rodin;I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;T. von Danwitz;M. Safjan;F. Biltgen;P.G. Xuereb;N. Piçarra;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: A general five-year PNR data retention period is unlawful; retention beyond six months requires objective material establishing a terrorism or serious crime risk for the specific passenger.
semantic_quote: The period during which PNR data are to be retained should be as long as is necessary for and proportionate to the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offences and serious crime.
systematic_quote: The interpretation of Article 12(1) of the PNR Directive must take into account the provisions in paragraphs 2 and 3 of that article, which lay down a set of rules for the retention of and access to PNR data.
teleological_quote: According to recital 25, those provisions seek to avoid disproportionate use through masking out of those data and to ensure the highest level of data protection.
direction_justification: Significantly limits data retention by requiring individualized risk assessment; general retention beyond six months for passengers without risk indicators is prohibited.
other_rights: public security;internal security

judges: K. Lenaerts;A. Arabadjiev;S. Rodin;I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;T. von Danwitz;M. Safjan;F. Biltgen;P.G. Xuereb;N. Piçarra;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: The API Directive does not apply to intra-EU flights; it applies only to flights crossing external borders between Member States and third countries.
semantic_quote: Article 3(1) of the API Directive provides that Member States are to take the necessary steps to establish an obligation for carriers to transmit information concerning the passengers they will carry to an authorised border crossing point through which these persons will enter the territory of a Member State.
systematic_quote: It is clear from those provisions, read in the light of Article 2(a), (b) and (d) of the API Directive, that that directive imposes the obligation for air carriers only in the case of flights transporting passengers to an authorised crossing point for crossing the Member States' external borders with third countries.
direction_justification: Clarifies territorial scope of API Directive without expanding or restricting data subject rights within that directive's framework.

judges: K. Lenaerts;A. Arabadjiev;S. Rodin;I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;T. von Danwitz;M. Safjan;F. Biltgen;P.G. Xuereb;N. Piçarra;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: Extension of PNR system to all intra-EU flights requires genuine terrorist threat; otherwise must be limited to selected flights with specific indications, and cannot serve border control or immigration purposes.
semantic_quote: Article 45 of the Charter guarantees the right of every citizen of the European Union to move and reside freely within the territory of the Member States.
systematic_quote: Article 67(2) TFEU provides that the European Union is to ensure the absence of internal border controls for persons and to frame a common policy on external border control.
teleological_quote: A national measure that is liable to obstruct the exercise of freedom of movement for persons may be justified only where such a measure is consistent with the fundamental rights guaranteed by the Charter.
direction_justification: Significantly restricts Member State power to extend PNR system to intra-EU transport; requires genuine terrorist threat or targeted selection with regular review.
other_rights: freedom of movement;public security;internal security

judges: K. Lenaerts;A. Arabadjiev;S. Rodin;I. Jarukaitis;N. Jääskinen;T. von Danwitz;M. Safjan;F. Biltgen;P.G. Xuereb;N. Piçarra;L.S. Rossi;A. Kumin;N. Wahl
core_holding: National courts cannot limit temporal effects of declaring national PNR legislation illegal; evidence admissibility is for national law subject to equivalence and effectiveness principles.
provisions_cited: Article 3(2) TEU;Article 67(2) TFEU;Article 7 Charter;Article 8 Charter;Article 45 Charter;Article 52(1) Charter
systematic_quote: The principle of the primacy of EU law establishes the pre-eminence of EU law over the law of the Member States, requiring all Member State bodies to give full effect to the various provisions of EU law.
teleological_quote: Maintaining the effects of national legislation would mean that that legislation would continue to impose on air carriers and other carriers obligations which are contrary to EU law and which seriously interfere with the fundamental rights.
direction_justification: Prevents national courts from temporarily maintaining illegal surveillance legislation, ensuring immediate effect of Charter-based invalidity findings.
